COMMITTEE AMENDMENT L.D. 1019 1 
 2 
 
MAJORITY 
APPROPRIATIONS AND FINANCIAL AFFAIRS 3 
Reproduced and distributed under the direction of the Clerk of the House. 4 
STATE OF MAINE 5 
HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 6 
127TH LEGISLATURE 7 
FIRST REGULAR SESSION 8 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019, Bill, “An Act Making 9 
Unified Appropriations and Allocations for the Expenditures of State Government, 10 
General Fund and Other Funds and Changing Certain Provisions of the Law Necessary to 11 
the Proper Operations of State Government for the Fiscal Years Ending June 30, 2016 12 
and June 30, 2017”  13 
Amend the bill by striking out the title and substituting the following: 14 
'An Act Making Unified Appropriations and Allocations for the Expenditures of 15 
State Government, General Fund and Other Funds and Changing Certain 16 
Provisions of the Law Necessary to the Proper Operations of State Government for 17 
the Fiscal Years Ending June 30, 2015, June 30, 2016 and June 30, 2017 '  18 
Amend the bill by striking out everything after the title and inserting the following: 19 
'Emergency preamble. Whereas, acts and resolves of the Legislature do not 20 
become effective until 90 days after adjournment unless enacted as emergencies; and 21 
Whereas, the 90-day period may not terminate until after the beginning of the next 22 
fiscal year; and 23 
Whereas, certain obligations and expenses incident to the operation of state 24 
departments and institutions will become due and payable immediately; and 25 
Whereas, in the judgment of the Legislature, these facts create an emergency within 26 
the meaning of the Constitution of Maine and require the following legislation as 27 
immediately necessary for the preservation of the public peace, health and safety; now, 28 
therefore, 29 
Be it enacted by the People of the State of Maine as follows: 30 
31 Date: 6-12-15 (Filing No. H -415) 
COMMI TTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 2  - 127LR1852(02)-1

COMMI TTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 6  - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT Initiative: Transfers one Office Associate II position from the State Lottery Fund, Lottery 1 
Operations program, to the Alcoholic Beverages Fund, Alcoholic Beverages - General 2 
Operation program. This initiative also transfers one part-time Office Associate II 3 
position from the State Lottery Fund, Lottery Operations program, to the General Fund, 4 
Bureau of Alcoholic Beverages program, increases the hours from 34 hours biweekly to 5 
80 hours biweekly and provides funding for associated All Other costs. 6

more accurately reflect the work performed within the Division of Licensing and 21 
Enforcement, Alcoholic Beverages - General Operation program. 22

and Enforcement, Alcoholic Beverages - General Operation program. 30

Central Services - Purchases 0004  8 
Initiative: Transfers one Inventory and Property Associate I position and incumbent 9 
personnel from the Department of Administrative and Financial Services, Central 10 
Services - Purchases program, Postal, Printing and Supply Fund to the Department of 11 
Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry, Office of the Commissioner program, Other 12 
Special Revenue Funds.  The employee retains all rights as a classified employee as well 13 
as all accrued fringe benefits, including but not limited to vacation and sick leave, health 14 
and life insurance and retirement benefits. 15 
 
 16 
 17 
 18 
 19 
 20 
 
 21 
Central Services - Purchases 0004  22 
Initiative: Transfers one Inventory and Property Associate II Supervisor position and 23 
incumbent personnel from the Department of Administrative and Financial Services, 24 
Central Services - Purchases program, Postal, Printing and Supply Fund to the 25 
Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife, Office of the Commissioner - Inland 26 
Fisheries and Wildlife program, Other Special Revenue Funds.  The employee retains all 27 
rights as a classified employee as well as all accrued fringe benefits, including but not 28 
limited to vacation and sick leave, health and life insurance and retirement benefits. 29

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT Lottery Operations 0023  1 
Initiative: Transfers one Office Associate II position from the State Lottery Fund, Lottery 2 
Operations program, to the Alcoholic Beverages Fund, Alcoholic Beverages - General 3 
Operation program. This initiative also transfers one part-time Office Associate II 4 
position from the State Lottery Fund, Lottery Operations program, to the General Fund, 5 
Bureau of Alcoholic Beverages program, increases the hours from 34 hours biweekly to 6 
80 hours biweekly and provides funding for associated All Other costs. 7

Initiative: Transfers and reallocates one Director of Forestry position from the 31 
Administration - Forestry program to the Forest Health and Monitoring program funded 32

program and transfers All Other in the Administration - Forestry program to the Forest 36 
Health and Monitoring program. 37

Long Creek Youth Development Center 0163  12 
Initiative: Transfers 2 Education Specialist II positions and 2 Office Associate II positions 13 
from the General Purpose Aid for Local Schools program within the Department of 14 
Education to one of each in the Long Creek Youth Development Center program and the 15 
Mountain View Youth Development Center program within the Department of 16 
Corrections.  The headcount for these positions will be offset by a reduction in headcount 17 
by the Department of Education and the positions will be funded by the General Purpose 18 
Aid for Local Schools program. 19

program to the State Prison program. 14

Community Development Block Grant Program 0587  8 
Initiative: Reorganizes one Public Service Manager II position to a Public Service 9 
Coordinator II position and transfers the position from the Community Development 10 
Block Grant Program, Federal Block Grant Fund to the International Commerce program, 11 
General Fund.  Also provides funding for All Other costs to permanently establish the 12 
Maine North Atlantic development office at the Maine International Trade Center. 13

100% Community Development Block Grant Program, Federal Block Grant Fund to 50% 23 
Community Development Block Grant Program, Federal Block Grant Fund and 50% 24 
Office of Tourism program, Other Special Revenue Funds and adjusts funding for related 25 
STA-CAP charges. 26

Revenue Funds to 75% Federal Block Grant Fund and 25% General Fund within the 35 
same program and adjusts funding for related STA-CAP charges. 36

General Purpose Aid for Local Schools 0308  14 
Initiative: Transfers 2 Education Specialist II positions and 2 Office Associate II positions 15 
from the General Purpose Aid for Local Schools program to one of each in the Long 16 
Creek Youth Development Center program and the Mountain View Youth Development 17 
Center program in the Department of Corrections and transfers funding from the Personal 18 
Services line category to the All Other line category.  The reduction in headcount for 19 
these positions will be offset by an increase in headcount in the Department of 20 
Corrections and the positions will be funded from the All Other line category in the 21 
General Purpose Aid for Local Schools program. 22

General Purpose Aid for Local Schools 0308  5 
Initiative: Reallocates the cost of one Public Service Manager II position from 30% in the 6 
General Purpose Aid for Local Schools program, General Fund and 70% in the 7 
Leadership Team program, Other Special Revenue Funds to 100% in the General Purpose 8 
Aid for Local Schools program, General Fund and transfers funding from the All Other 9 
category to the Personal Services line category to fund the reallocation. 10

General Purpose Aid for Local Schools 0308  17 
Initiative: Transfers the cost of one Office Associate II position from 100% Federal 18 
Expenditures Fund to 100% General Fund within the PK-20, Adult Education and 19 
Federal Programs Team program and increases the number of hours of the position from 20 
58 hours to 80 hours biweekly.  This initiative also transfers All Other in the General 21 
Purpose Aid for Local Schools program to Personal Services in the PK-20, Adult 22 
Education and Federal Programs Team program to fund the position. 23

Programs Team program, Federal Expenditures Fund to the General Purpose Aid for 32 
Local Schools program, General Fund.  Also transfers All Other to Personal Services in 33 
the General Purpose Aid for Local Schools program, General Fund to fund the 34 
continuation of the position. 35

General Purpose Aid for Local Schools 0308  29 
Initiative: Reorganizes one Chief Academic Officer position to a Public Servic e 30 
Executive II position in the PK-20, Adult Education and Federal Programs Team 31 
program, General Fund, one Director of Special Service Team position to a Public 32 
Service Executive II position in the Special Services Team program, Federal 33 
Expenditures Fund and one Public Service Coordinator II position to a Public Service 34 
Manager II position in the Leadership Team program, General Fund.  Eliminates one 35 
Public Service Executive II position in the Leadership Team program.  Reorganizes one 36 
Public Service Executive II position to a Regional Education Representative position and 37 
transfers the position from the Leadership Team program to PK-20, Adult Education and 38 
Federal Programs Team program within the same fund.  This initiative also provides 39 
funding for the range change of one Public Service Executive II position in the General 40 
Purpose Aid for Local Schools program, General Fund. 41 GENERAL FUND  2015 -16 2016 -17

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 599 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  
PART C 1 
Sec. C -1.  20 -A MRSA §4251, as amended by PL 1989, c. 548, §2, is further 2 
amended to read: 3 
§4251.  Intent 4 
The intent of this subchapter is to encourage school administrative units to place an 5 
increased emphasis on instruction and curriculum for all children ages 4 to 9 beginning at 6 
4 years of age in public preschool programs to grade 2.  This subchapter is not intended 7 
as a method of financing existing efforts but as a way of encouraging the development of 8 
new or expanded programs. 9 
Sec. C -2.  20 -A MRSA §4252, sub-§1, as enacted by PL 1983, c. 576, §1, is 10 
amended to read: 11 
1.  Class size.   Reduce the student-teacher ratio class size in all classrooms within 12 
one or more grades, kindergarten through grade 3, to a recommended ratio of 15 to 1 and 13 
maximum ratio of 18 to 1; 14 
Sec. C -3.  20 -A MRSA §4722-A, sub-§4, as enacted by PL 2011, c. 669, §7, is 15 
amended to read: 16 
4.  Grants; contingent extension of full implementation.   During the period of 17 
transition to proficiency-based graduation in accordance with this section, the department, 18 
if funds are available, shall make annual transition grants to each school administrative 19 
unit equal to 1/10 of 1% of the school administrative unit's total cost of education 20 
calculated under section 15688, subsection 1 to be used in the manner determined by the 21 
school administrative unit to fund the costs of the transition not otherwise subsidized by 22 
the State through the 2014-2015 school year.  The date for implementation of the 23 
awarding of diplomas based on student demonstration of proficiency as described in this 24 
section is extended one year for each year for which transition grants are not made 25 
available to a school administrative unit or for which levels of general purpose aid for 26 
local schools fall below school year 2012-2013 levels.  Beginning in the 2015-2016 27 
school year, the department, if funds are available, shall make annual transition grants to 28 
each school administrative unit that operates schools equal to 1/9 of 1% of the school 29 
administrative unit's total cost of education calculated under section 15688, subsection 1 30 
to be used in the manner determined by the school administrative unit to fund the costs of 31 
the transition not otherwise subsidized by the State. 32 
Sec. C -4.  20 -A MRSA §15671, sub-§1 -A, as enacted by PL 2013, c. 368, Pt. C, 33 
§4, is amended to read: 34 
1-A.  State funding for kindergarten to grade 12 public education.  Beginning in 35 
fiscal year 2015-16 2016-17 and in each fiscal year thereafter until the state share 36 
percentage of the total cost of funding public education from kindergarten to grade 12 37 
reaches 55% pursuant to subsection 7, paragraph B, the State shall increase the state share 38 
percentage of the funding for the cost of essential programs and services by at least one 39 
percentage point per year over the percentage of the previous year and the department, in 40 
COMMI TTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 600 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT allocating funds, shall make this increase in funding a priority.  For those fiscal years that 1 
the funding appropriated or allocated for the cost of essential programs and services is not 2 
sufficient to increase the state share percentage of the total cost of funding public 3 
education from kindergarten to grade 12 by at least one percentage point, no new 4 
programs or initiatives may be established for kindergarten to grade 12 public education 5 
within the department that would divert funds that would otherwise be distributed as 6 
general purpose aid for local schools pursuant to subsection 5. 7 
Sec. C -5.  20 -A MRSA §15671, sub-§5 -A, as amended by PL 2013, c. 581, §6, 8 
is further amended to read: 9 
5-A.  Funds from casino slot machines or table games.  Revenues received by the 10 
department from casino slot machines or casino table games pursuant to Title 8, section 11 
1036, subsection 2-A, paragraph A or Title 8, section 1036, subsection 2-B, paragraph A 12 
must be distributed until the end of fiscal year 2014-15 as general purpose aid for local 13 
schools, and each school administrative unit shall make its own determination as to how 14 
to allocate these resources.  Beginning in fiscal year 2015-16  2017-18, $4,000,000 in 15 
revenues must be distributed by the department to provide start-up funds for approved 16 
public preschool programs for children 4 years of age in accordance with chapter 203, 17 
subchapter 3.  Neither the Governor nor the Legislature may divert the revenues payable 18 
to the department to any other fund or for any other use. Any proposal to enact or amend 19 
a law to allow distribution of the revenues paid to the department from casino slot 20 
machines or casino table games for another purpose must be submitted to the Legislative 21 
Council and to the joint standing committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over 22 
education matters at least 30 days prior to any vote or public hearing on the proposal. 23 
Sec. C -6.  20 -A MRSA §15671, sub-§7, ¶B, as amended by PL 2013, c. 595, Pt. 24 
C, §1, is further amended to read: 25

cost of the components of essential programs and services are as follows. 27

(9) For fiscal year 2013-14, the target is 47.29%. 36 
(10)  For fiscal year 2014-15, the target is 46.80%. 37 
(11) For fiscal year 2015-16, the target is 47.54%. 38

Sec. C -8.  20 -A MRSA §15671-A, sub-§2, ¶B, as amended by PL 2013, c. 595, 14 
Pt. C, §3, is further amended to read: 15 
B.  For property tax years beginning on or after April 1, 2005, the commissioner shall 16 
calculate the full-value education mill rate that is required to raise the statewide total 17 
local share.  The full-value education mill rate is calculated for each fiscal year by 18 
dividing the applicable statewide total local share by the applicable statewide 19 
valuation.  The full-value education mill rate must decline over the period from fiscal 20 
year 2005-06 to fiscal year 2008-09 and may not exceed 9.0 mills in fiscal year 2005- 21 
06 and may not exceed 8.0 mills in fiscal year 2008-09.  The full-value education mill 22 
rate must be applied according to section 15688, subsection 3-A, paragraph A to 23 
determine a municipality's local cost share expectation.  Full-value education mill 24 
rates must be derived according to the following schedule. 25 
(1)  For the 2005 property tax year, the full-value education mill rate is the 26 
amount necessary to result in a 47.4% statewide total local share in fiscal year 27 
2005-06.  28 
(2)  For the 2006 property tax year, the full-value education mill rate is the 29 
amount necessary to result in a 46.14% statewide total local share in fiscal year 30 
2006-07.  31 
(3)  For the 2007 property tax year, the full-value education mill rate is the 32 
amount necessary to result in a 46.49% statewide total local share in fiscal year 33 
2007-08.  34 
(4)  For the 2008 property tax year, the full-value education mill rate is the 35 
amount necessary to result in a 47.48% statewide total local share in fiscal year 36 
2008-09.  37

Sec. C -9.  20 -A MRSA §15681-A, sub-§4, as amended by PL 2013, c. 595, Pt. 25 
C, §4, is further amended to read: 26 
4.  Career and technical education costs.   Career and technical education costs in 27 
the base year adjusted to the year prior to the allocation year.  This subsection does not 28 
apply to the 2015-16 2017-18 funding year and thereafter; and 29 
Sec. C -10.  20 -A MRSA §15688-A, sub-§1, as amended by PL 2013, c. 595, Pt. 30 
C, §5, is further amended to read: 31 
1.  Career and technical education costs.  Beginning in fiscal year 2015-16 2017 - 32 
18, the allocation for career and technical education must be based upon a program- 33 
driven model that considers components for direct instruction, central administration, 34 
supplies, operation and maintenance of plant, other student and staff support and 35 
equipment.  Monthly payments must be made directly to school administrative units with 36 
career and technical education centers and directly to career and technical education 37 
regions. If a school administrative unit with a career and technical education center or a 38 
career and technical education region has any unexpended funds at the end of the fiscal 39 
year, these funds must be carried forward for the purposes of career and technical 40 
education. 41

 Page 603 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT Sec. C-11.  20 -A MRSA §15688-A, sub-§§5 to 7 are enacted to read: 1 
5.  School improvement and support.   The commissioner may expend and disburse 2 
funds to support school improvement activities in accordance with chapter 222. 3 
6.  National industry standards for career and technical education.   The 4 
commissioner may expend and disburse funds to support enhancements to career and 5 
technical education programs that align those programs with national industry standards, 6 
in accordance with chapter 313. 7 
7.  Educator effectiveness.   The commissioner may expend and disburse funds to 8 
support the implementation of performance evaluation and professional growth systems 9 
in accordance with chapter 508. 10 
Sec. C-12.  20 -A MRSA §15689, sub-§2, ¶C is enacted to read: 11 
C.  Beginning in fiscal year 2016-17, the debt service adjustment in this subsection 12 
must be applied to each member municipality of a school administrative district, 13 
community school district and regional school unit. 14 
Sec. C -13.  20-A MRSA §15689-A, sub-§18, as amended by PL 2009, c. 213, 15 
Pt. C, §13, is further amended to read: 16 
18.  Coordination of services for juvenile offenders.   The commissioner may pay 17 
certain costs attributed to staff support consisting of 2 Education Specialist II positions 18 
and 2 Office Associate II positions and associated operating costs for providing 19 
coordination of education, treatment and other services for juvenile offenders at youth 20 
development centers in Charleston and South Portland. A transfer of All Other funds 21 
from the General Purpose Aid for Local Schools account to the All Other line category in 22 
the Special Services Team program General Fund account within the Department of 23 
Education sufficient to support the All Other costs in this subsection Personal Services 24 
and All Other line categories in the Long Creek Youth Development Center, General 25 
Fund account within the Department of Corrections sufficient to support one Education 26 
Specialist II position and one Office Associate II position and to the Mountain View 27 
Youth Development Center, General Fund account within the Department of Corrections 28 
sufficient to support one Education Specialist II position and one Office Associate II 29 
position may occur annually by financial order upon recommendation of the State Budget 30 
Officer and approval of the Governor. 31

Sec. C -16.  Maine Revised Statutes headnote amended; revision clause.  In 36 
the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 20-A, chapter 203, subchapter 2,  in the subchapter 37 
headnote, the words "early childhood educational plans for children ages 4 to 9" are 38 
amended to read "early childhood educational plans for children in preschool to grade 2" 39 
and the Revisor of Statutes shall implement this revision when updating, publishing or 40 
republishing the statutes. 41

Sec. K-3.  36 MRSA §683, sub-§5, as enacted by PL 2005, c. 647, §4 and 21 
affected by §5, is amended to read: 22 
5.  Determination of exemption for cooperative housing corporation.   A 23 
cooperative housing corporation may apply for an exemption under this subchapter to be 24 
applied against the valuation of property of the corporation that is occupied by qualifying 25 
shareholders.  The application must include a list of all qualifying shareholders and must 26 
be updated annually to reflect changes in the ownership and residency of qualifying 27 
shareholders.  The exemption is equal to the amount amounts specified in subsection 28 
subsections 1 and 1-B multiplied by the number of units in the cooperative property 29 
occupied by qualifying shareholders.  A cooperative housing corporation that receives an 30 
exemption pursuant to this section shall apportion the property tax reduction resulting 31 
from the exemption among the qualifying shareholders on a per unit basis.  Any 32 
supplemental assessment resulting from disqualification for exemption must be applied in 33 
the same manner against the qualifying shareholders for whom the disqualification 34 
applies. 35

further amended to read: 12 
2.  Average personal income growt h.  "Average real personal income growth" 13 
means the average for the prior 10 calendar years, ending with the most recent calendar 14 
year for which data is available, of the percent change in personal income in this State, as 15 
estimated by the United States Department of Commerce, Bureau of Economic Analysis , 16 
less the percent change in the Consumer Price Index for the calendar year.  The average 17 
real personal income growth is determined by October 1st, annually, by the Governor's 18 
Office of Policy and Management. 19

Sec. M-6.  5 MRSA §1532, sub-§§1 and 5, as enacted by PL 2005, c. 2, Pt. A, 26 
§5 and affected by §14, are amended to read: 27 
1.  Generally; stabilization fund established.   The Maine Budget Stabilization Fund 28 
is hereby established.  Amounts in the stabilization fund may not exceed 12% 18% of 29 
total General Fund revenues in the immediately preceding state fiscal year and, except as 30 
provided by section 1533, may not be reduced below 1% of total General Fund revenue in 31 
the immediately preceding state fiscal year.  For the purposes of this subsection, at the 32 
close of a fiscal year, "immediately preceding state fiscal year" means the fiscal year that 33 
is being closed. 34 
5.  Investment proceeds; exception.  At the close of every month during which the 35 
stabilization fund is at the 12% 18% limitation described in subsection 1, the State 36 
Controller shall transfer from the General Fund to the Retirement Allowance Fund 37 
established in section 17251 an amount equal to the investment earnings that otherwise 38 
would have been credited to the stabilization fund. 39

COMMI TTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 612 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT 2.  Growth limitation factor.   The growth limitation factor is calculated as follows 1 
the average personal income growth. 2 
A.    For  fiscal years when the State Tax Assessor has determined that the state and 3 
local tax burden ranks in the highest 1/3 of all states, the growth limitation factor is 4 
average real personal income growth, but no more than 2.75%, plus average 5 
population growth. 6 
B.    For fiscal years when the state and local tax burden ranks in the middle 1/3 of all 7 
states, as determined by the State Tax Assessor, the growth limitation factor is 8 
average real personal income growth plus forecasted inflation plus average 9 
population growth. 10

further amended to read: 4 
1.  Expenditure and appropriation requirements.   On or before September 1st of 5 
the even-numbered years, all departments and other agencies of the State Government 6 
and corporations and associations receiving or desiring to receive state funds under the 7 
provisions of law shall prepare, in the manner prescribed by the State Budget Officer, and 8 
submit to the officer estimates of their expenditure and appropriation requirements for 9 
each fiscal year of the ensuing biennium.  The expenditure estimates must be classified to 10 
set forth the data by funds, organization units, character and objects of expenditure. The 11 
organization units may be subclassified by functions and activities, or in any other 12 
manner, at the discretion of the State Budget Officer. 13 
All departments and other agencies receiving or desiring to receive state funds from the 14 
Highway Fund shall submit to the officer estimates of their expenditure and appropriation 15 
requirements for each fiscal year of the ensuing biennium that do not exceed the Highway 16 
Fund appropriation of the previous fiscal year multiplied by one plus the average real 17 
personal income growth rate or 2.75%, whichever is less.  The Highway Fund highway 18 
and bridge improvement accounts are exempt from this spending limitation. 19 
The State Budget Officer shall request that the Governor provide the budget proposal for 20 
the Maine Indian Tribal-State Commission developed pursuant to Title 30, section 6212, 21 
subsection 6. 22

B.  By fiscal year 2008-09 the state share of the total cost of funding public education 4

Sec. M-11.  30 -A MRSA §706-A, sub-§1, as amended by PL 2007, c. 653, Pt. A, 13 
§10, is further amended to read: 14 
1.  Definitions.   As used in this section, unless the context otherwise indicates, the 15 
following terms have the following meanings. 16 
A.  "Average real personal income growth" has the same meaning as under Title 5, 17 
section 1531, subsection 2. 18 
B.  "County assessment" means: 19 
(1)  For the tax year of any county that began prior to January 1, 2009, total 20 
annual county appropriations reduced by all resources available to fund those 21 
appropriations other than the county tax; or 22 
(2)  For the tax year of any county that begins on or after January 1, 2009, total 23 
annual county appropriations for noncorrectional-related services as established 24 
in section 701, reduced by all resources available to fund those appropriations 25 
other than the county tax. 26 
C.    "Forecasted inflation" has the same meaning as under Title 5, section 1531, 27 
subsection 6. 28 
D.  "Property growth factor" means the percentage equivalent to a fraction, whose 29 
denominator is the total valuation of all municipalities, plantations and unorganized 30 
territory in the county, and whose numerator is the amount of increase in the assessed 31 
valuation of any real or personal property in those jurisdictions that became subject to 32 
taxation for the first time, or taxed as a separate parcel for the first time for the most 33 
recent property tax year for which information is available, or that has had an 34 
increase in its assessed valuation over the prior year's valuation as a result of 35 
improvements to or expansion of the property.  The State Tax Assessor shall provide 36 
to the counties forms and a methodology for the calculation of the property growth 37 
factor, and the counties shall use those forms and the methodology to establish the 38 
property growth factor. 39 
E.    "State and local tax burden" has the same meaning as under Title 5, section 40 
1531, subsection 9. 41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 615 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT Sec. M-12.  30 -A MRSA §706-A, sub-§3, as enacted by PL 2005, c. 2, Pt. B, §1 1 
and affected by §§2 and 4 and c. 12, Pt. WW, §14, is amended to read: 2 
3.  Growth limitation factor.   The growth limitation factor is calculated as follows 3 
the average personal income growth plus the property growth factor. 4 
A.    For  fiscal years when the State Tax Assessor has determined that the state and 5 
local tax burden ranks in the highest 1/3 of all states, the growth limitation factor is 6 
average real personal income growth but no more than 2.75%, plus the property 7 
growth factor. 8 
B.    For fiscal years when the state and local tax burden ranks in the middle 1/3 of all 9 
states, as determined by the State Tax Assessor, the growth limitation factor is the 10 
average real personal income growth plus forecasted inflation plus the property 11 
growth factor. 12

section 1531, subsection 2. 16

Sec. M-16.  30 -A MRSA §5721-A, sub-§3, as enacted by PL 2005, c. 2, Pt. C, 21 
§1 and affected by §§3 and 5 and c. 12, Pt. WW, §16, is amended to read: 22 
3.  Growth limitation factor.   The growth limitation factor is calculated as follows 23 
the average personal income growth plus the property growth factor. 24 
A.    For  fiscal years when the State Tax Assessor has determined that the state and 25 
local tax burden ranks in the highest 1/3 of all states, the growth limitation factor is 26 
average real personal income growth but no more than 2.75%, plus the property 27 
growth factor. 28 
B.    For fiscal years when the state and local tax burden ranks in the middle 1/3 of all 29 
states, as determined by the State Tax Assessor, the growth limitation factor is the 30 
average real personal income growth plus forecasted inflation plus the property 31 
growth factor. 32

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT PART P 1 
Sec. P-1.  Tax expenditures.  In accordance with the Maine Revised Statutes, 2 
Title 5, section 1666 and to the extent not otherwise provided in this Act, funding is 3 
continued for each individual tax expenditure, as defined in Title 5, section 1666, 4 
reported in the budget document submitted to the Legislature by the Governor on January 5 
9, 2015. 6 
PART Q 7 
Sec. Q-1.  Attrition savings.   Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the 8 
attrition rate for the 2016-2017 biennium is increased from 1.6% to 3% for judicial 9 
branch and executive branch departments and agencies only, with the exception of the 10 
District Attorneys Salaries program within the Department of the Attorney General.  The 11 
attrition rate for subsequent biennia is 1.6% with the exception of the District Attorneys 12 
Salaries program within the Department of the Attorney General. The attrition rate for the 13 
District Attorneys Salaries program is 0% for the 2016-2017 biennium. 14 
Sec. Q-2.  Calculation and transfer.   Notwithstanding any other provision of 15 
law, the State Budget Officer shall calculate the amount of savings in this Part that 16 
applies against each General Fund account for all executive branch departments and 17 
agencies from savings associated with attrition in fiscal year 2015-16 and fiscal year 18 
2016-17 and shall transfer the amounts by financial order upon the approval of the 19 
Governor. These transfers are considered adjustments to appropriations in fiscal year 20 
2015-16 and fiscal year 2016-17. The State Budget Officer shall provide a report of the 21 
transferred amounts to the Joint Standing Committee on Appropriations and Financial 22 
Affairs no later than October 1, 2015. 23 
Sec. Q-3.  Application of attrition savings.   The State Budget Officer shall 24 
consider the size of an agency when developing a process to ensure agency compliance 25 
with budgeted attrition savings.  Agencies with 50 or fewer legislatively authorized 26 
positions must be given an opportunity to justify any deviation from the established 27 
savings target to the State Budget Officer. The State Budget Officer may reassign the 28 
unrealized attrition savings to another agency.  In no event may an agency's ability to 29 
achieve attrition savings in one fiscal year have any effect on another fiscal year’s 30 
attrition savings target. 31 
Sec. Q-4.  Appropriations and allocations.  The following appropriations and 32 
allocations are made. 33 
ADMINISTRATIVE AND FINANCIAL SERVICES, DEPARTMENT OF 34 
Executive Branch Departments and Independent Agencies - Statewide 0017 35 
Initiative:  Reduces funding to reflect projected savings from an increase in the attrition 36 
rate from 1.6% to 3% for fiscal years 2015-16 and 2016-17. 37

Sec. EE-1.  36 MRSA §5122, sub-§2, ¶M-2 is enacted to read: 20 
M-2.  For tax years beginning on or after January 1, 2016: 21 
(1)  For each individual who is a primary recipient of retirement plan benefits, the 22 
reduction is the sum of: 23 
(a)  Excluding military retirement plan benefits, an amount that is the lesser 24 
of the aggregate of retirement plan benefits under employee retirement plans 25 
or individual retirement accounts included in the individual’s federal adjusted 26 
gross income and the pension deduction amount.  The amount claimed under 27 
this division must be reduced by the total amount of the individual’s social 28 
security benefits and railroad retirement benefits paid by the United States, 29 
but not less than $0; and 30 
(b) An amount that is the lesser of the aggregate of retirement benefits under 31 
military retirement plans included in the individual’s federal adjusted gross 32 
income and $25,000; and 33 
(2)  For purposes of this paragraph, the following terms have the following 34 
meanings. 35 
(a)  "Employee retirement plan" means a state, federal or military retirement 36 
plan or any other retirement benefit plan established and maintained by an 37 
employer for the benefit of its employees under the Code, Section 401(a), 38 
Section 403 or Section 457(b), except that distributions made pursuant to a 39 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 623 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT Section 457(b) plan are not eligible for the deduction provided by this 1 
paragraph if they are made prior to age 55 and are not part of a series of 2 
substantially equal periodic payments made for the life of the primary 3 
recipient or the joint lives of the primary recipient and that recipient's 4 
designated beneficiary. 5 
(b)  "Individual retirement account" means an individual retirement account 6 
under Section 408 of the Code, a Roth IRA under Section 408A of the Code, 7 
a simplified employee pension under Section 408(k) of the Code or a simple 8 
retirement account for employees under Section 408(p) of the Code. 9 
(c)  "Military retirement plan" means retirement plan benefits received as a 10 
result of service in the active or reserve components of the Army, Navy, Air 11 
Force, Marines or Coast Guard. 12 
(d)  "Pension deduction amount" means $10,000 for tax years beginning in 13 
2014.   14 
(e)  "Primary recipient" means the individual upon whose earnings or 15 
contributions the retirement plan benefits are based or the surviving spouse of 16 
that individual. 17 
(f)  "Retirement plan benefits" means employee retirement plan benefits, 18 
except pick-up contributions for which a subtraction is allowed under 19 
paragraph E, reported as pension or annuity income for federal income tax 20 
purposes and individual retirement account benefits reported as individual 21 
retirement account distributions for federal income tax purposes.  22

the tax imposed by the Code, Section 72(t); 24

COMMI TTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 624 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT §1807.  Sustainable harvest level 1 
Except as provided in this section, timber harvesting on public reserved lands and 2 
nonreserved public lands may not exceed in total an average of 160,000 cords per year 3 
over any 3-year period.  If an independent timber inventory conducted after July 1, 2015 4 
establishes a different sustainable harvest, the department may adopt by rule a different 5 
harvesting level consistent with that inventory.  Rules adopted pursuant to this section are 6 
major substantive rules as defined in Title 5, chapter 375, subchapter 2-A and must be 7 
reviewed by the joint standing committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over 8 
public reserved and nonreserved lands matters. 9

Sec. HH-2.  5 MRSA §3360-N, as enacted by PL 2001, c. 439, Pt. Z, §1, is 15

§3360-N.  Sexual Assault Forensic Examiner Advisory Board established; 17 
membership 18 
1.  Establishment and membership.   The Sexual Assault Forensic Examiner 19 
Advisory Board, referred to in this chapter as the "board," established under section 20 
12004-J, subsection 13, is established within the Department of the Attorney General 21 
Health and Human Services.  The board consists of 13 members appointed by the 22 
Attorney General Commissioner of Health and Human Services.  Members must include 23 
the following: 24 
A.  One physician licensed to practice medicine in the State; 25 
B.  One member of the State Board of Nursing; 26 
C.  One sexual assault nurse examiner; 27 
D.  One representative from a sexual assault center; 28 
E.  One member from a statewide coalition against sexual assault; 29 
F.  One survivor of sexual assault; 30 
G.  One attorney from the Department of the Attorney General, designated by the 31 
Attorney General; 32 
H.  One employee of the Maine State Police Crime Laboratory; 33 
I.  One member from a statewide association of prosecutors; 34 
J.  One member from a statewide association of hospitals; 35 
K.  One member who is a forensic pediatric health care provider; and 36 
L.  Two public members. 37 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 625 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT 2.  Terms of appointment.   The term of each member of the board is 3 years.  When 1 
a vacancy occurs prior to the expiration of a term, the appointment to fill that vacancy is 2 
for the balance of the unexpired term.  Notwithstanding this subsection, the Attorney 3 
General may appoint initial members of the board for terms of fewer than 3 years to 4 
ensure staggered terms. 5 
3.  Chair.   The Commissioner of Health and Human Services shall appoint a member 6 
to be appointed by the Attorney General pursuant to subsection 1, paragraph G shall act 7 
as the chair of the board. 8 
4.  Meetings.   The board may not meet more than once a month. 9 
5.  Quorum.   Five members of the board constitute a quorum. 10

amended to read: 12 
§3360-P.  Administration 13

general administrative oversight for the board's policies and responsibilities.  When 15 
appropriate, the Department of the Attorney General Health and Human Services may 16 
employ personnel necessary to carry out the purposes of the board; lease, rent or acquire 17 
adequate equipment and facilities; accept federal funds or grants that are available to 18 
carry out or implement the board's objectives; and provide technical assistance and 19 
training to sexual assault forensic examiners. 20

PART JJ 29 
Sec. JJ-1.  22 MRSA §4307, sub-§4,  as corrected by RR 2009, c. 2, §58, is 30 
amended to read: 31 
4.  Special circumstances.  Overseers of a municipality may not move or transport 32 
an applicant or recipient into another municipality to relieve their municipality of 33 
responsibility for that applicant's or recipient's support.  The municipality of 34 
responsibility for relocations, persons released from correctional facilities and 35 
institutional settings is as follows.  36 
A.  When an applicant or recipient requests relocation to another municipality and the 37 
overseers of a municipality assist that person to relocate to another municipality, the 38 
municipality from which that person is moving continues to be responsible for the 39 
COMMI TTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 626 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT support of the recipient for 30 days after relocation.  As used in this paragraph, 1 
"assist" includes:  2 
(1)  Granting financial assistance to relocate; and  3 
(2)  Making arrangements for a person to relocate. 4 
B.  If an applicant is in a group home, shelter, rehabilitation center, nursing home, 5 
hospital or other institution at the time of application and has either been in that 6 
institution for 6 months or less, or had a residence immediately prior to entering the 7 
institution which the applicant had maintained and to which the applicant intends to 8 
return, the municipality of responsibility is the municipality where the applicant was 9 
a resident immediately prior to entering the institution.  For the purpose of this 10 
paragraph, a hotel, motel or similar place of temporary lodging is considered an 11 
institution when a municipality:  12 
(1)  Grants financial assistance for a person to move to or stay in temporary 13 
lodging;  14 
(2)  Makes arrangements for a person to stay in temporary lodging;  15 
(3)  Advises or encourages a person to stay in temporary lodging; or  16 
(4)  Illegally denies housing assistance and, as a result of that denial, the person 17 
stays in temporary lodging. 18 
C.  If an applicant has been released from a correctional facility within 45 days of 19 
application, the municipality of responsibility for the first 12 months of payment of 20 
benefits is the municipality that was on record as the residence of the applicant when 21 
the applicant was committed to the correctional facility. A municipality of 22 
responsibility must accept an application for general assistance by telephone if the 23 
applicant is calling from another municipal office, as long as the written application 24 
is contemporaneously faxed or sent electronically to the municipality of 25 
responsibility. 26 
PART KK 27 
Sec. KK-1.  Transfers and adjustments to position count.  The Commissioner 28 
of Corrections shall review the current organizational structure of the Department of 29 
Corrections to improve organizational efficiency and cost-effectiveness and shall 30 
recommend transfers of positions and available balances. Notwithstanding any other 31 
provision of law, the State Budget Officer shall transfer the position counts and available 32 
balances by financial order in order to achieve the purposes of this section from July 1st 33 
to December 1st of each fiscal year of the 2016-2017 biennium. Position adjustments 34 
made after December 1st and before July 1st of each fiscal year may not be an adjustment 35 
to position count or appropriations. In accordance with the requirements of the Maine 36 
Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 1585, a financial order describing such a transfer must 37 
be submitted by the Department of Administrative and Financial Services, Bureau of the 38 
Budget to the Office of Fiscal and Program Review 30 days before a transfer is to be 39 
implemented. In case of extraordinary emergency transfers, the 30-day prior submission 40 
requirement may be waived by vote of the joint standing committee of the Legislature 41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 627 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT having jurisdiction over appropriations and financial affairs. Any transfer or adjustment 1 
pursuant to this section that would result in a program or mission change or facility 2 
closure must be reported by the Bureau of the Budget to the joint standing committee of 3 
the Legislature having jurisdiction over criminal justice and public safety matters for 4 
review before the associated financial order is submitted to the Governor for approval. 5 
These transfers are considered adjustments to authorized position count, appropriations 6 
and allocations. 7 
Sec. KK-2.  Department of Corrections; quarterly reporting.  The 8 
Commissioner of Corrections shall provide quarterly reports to the joint standin g 9 
committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over appropriations and financial affairs 10 
and to the joint standing committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over criminal 11 
justice and public safety matters on the position transfers authorized pursuant to section 1 12 
of this Part.  The reports must detail, for both the sending and receiving program, the 13 
position title, the program name, an indication if the position was filled or vacant and the 14 
pay range and step if applicable.  The report must also include all position 15 
reclassifications, reorganizations and range changes that were approved during the 16 
previous quarter. 17

Sec. PP -1.  Lease -purchase authorization; Maine learning technology 2 
initiative.  Pursuant to the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 1587, the Department 3 
of Education may enter into financing arrangements in fiscal years 2015-16 and 2016-17 4

operations of the Maine learning technology initiative.  The financing agreements may 6 
not exceed 4 years in duration and $95,000,000 in principal costs for the Maine learning 7

may not exceed $7,600,000.  The annual principal and interest costs must be paid from 9 
the appropriate line category allocations in the Department of Education.  The State is 10 
authorized to extend the provisions of the lease-purchase agreement on behalf of school 11 
administrative units as long as all costs of the extension are borne by the school 12 
administrative units. 13

Sec. SS-2.  22 MRSA §8003, as enacted by PL 1975, c. 719, §6, is repealed and 16 
the following enacted in its place: 17 
§8003.  Fees and terms for licenses 18 
License fees and terms for drug treatment centers are governed by this section. 19 
1.  Provisional license.   The application fee for a provisional license for a drug 20 
treatment center may not be less than $100 nor more than $280.  The term of a 21 
provisional license is for one year. 22 
2.  Full license.   The application fee for a full license for a drug treatment center may 23 
not be less than $100 nor more than $280.  The term of a full license is for 2 years. 24 
3.  Biennial renewal of a full license.   The fee for the biennial renewal of a full 25 
license for a drug treatment center may not be less than $70 nor more than $170. 26 
4.  Adding a service site to a license.   The processing fee to add a service site to an 27 
issued license for a drug treatment center may not be less than $35 nor more than $70. 28 
5.  Adding a service to a license.   The processing fee to add a service to an issued 29 
license for a drug treatment center may not be less than $70 nor more than $140. 30 
6.  Fee to replace a license.   A licensee under this section shall maintain a valid 31 
license. An issued license is not valid when the information on the license is no longer 32 
accurate. A processing fee not to exceed $10 must be paid to the department to secure a 33 
reissued license with accurate information. The fee applies to each license replaced. The 34 
reissued license must have the same expiration date as the replaced license. 35 
7.  Transaction fee for electronic renewal of license.   The transaction fee for the 36 
electronic renewal of a license for a drug treatment center may not be less than $25 nor 37 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 631 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT more than $50. The transaction fee may not exceed the cost of providing the electronic 1 
renewal service. 2 
8.  Rules.   The department shall adopt rules to implement this section.  Rules adopted 3 
pursuant to this subsection are routine technical rules as defined in Title 5, chapter 375, 4 
subchapter 2- A. 5

PART TT 29 
Sec. TT-1.  Department of Health and Human Services to convene 30 
stakeholder group regarding methadone treatment.   The Department of Health 31 
and Human Services, referred to in this Part as "the department," shall convene a 32 
stakeholder group, including representatives of patients receiving methadone treatment 33 
and outpatient methadone treatment providers, consistent with state and federal law, for 34 
the purpose of developing criteria related to outpatient methadone treatment as set forth 35 
in this section. The stakeholder group shall conclude its work by November 15, 2015. 36 
1.  Treatment criteria.  The stakeholder group shall consider the establishment of 37 
criteria for receiving methadone treatment that may include one or more of the following: 38 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 633 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT A.  A physician's determination that methadone treatment is medically appropriate for 1 
a patient based on the criteria established by the American Society for Addiction 2 
Medicine or similar criteria; 3 
B.  Criteria involving a patient who had received opioid addiction treatment within 4 
the past 6 months under a treatment method other than methadone treatment, 5 
including detoxification treatment, medication-assisted treatment through 6 
buprenorphine or similar medication, abstinence-based treatment or other treatment 7 
method, and the treatment was determined by a physician trained in addiction 8 
medicine not to be effective or otherwise medically appropriate; or 9 
C.  Criteria involving a patient who sought opioid addiction treatment through a 10 
treatment method other than methadone treatment within the prior 6 months but was 11 
unable to obtain the treatment. 12 
The treatment criteria must include the requirement that a patient seeking methadone 13 
treatment be at least 18 years of age. A patient must be granted automatic approval to 14 
receive methadone treatment if treatment for the patient is court-ordered or the patient is 15 
pregnant. 16 
2.  Prior approval.  The stakeholder group shall review the department's existing 17 
criteria for prior approval of a patient to continue methadone treatment beyond 24 18 
months. The stakeholder group shall consider the need for additional criteria to ensure 19 
that methadone treatment continues to be medically appropriate for patients, including 20 
one or more of the following: 21 
A.  All applicable criteria for receiving treatment under subsection 1; 22 
B.  Evidence of active engagement in treatment services and supports; 23 
C.  Criteria for establishing a medication level at the lowest effective dosage as is 24 
medically appropriate for the patient; or 25 
D.  Evidence of progress in at least one of the following categories:  26 
(1)  Reunification with family; 27 
(2)  Employment or engagement in education or volunteer work; 28 
(3)  A reduction in illicit behavior related to addiction in the preceding 6 months; 29 
(4)  Physical health improvement; or 30 
(5)  Engagement in spiritual or community activities. 31 
3.  Treatment services.   The stakeholder group shall review opportunities to create a 32 
care delivery model focused on progress, recovery and reintegration through improved 33 
oversight, including opportunities to reduce transportation costs, improve staffing and 34 
services and improve the cost-effectiveness of treatment services. The review shall 35 
consider the level of services available through other treatment methods and include, but 36 
not be limited to, the services provided by an on-site medical director or designee, on-site 37 
behavioral health and addiction counseling services and vocational and educational 38 
services and the appropriate development, as needed, of quality improvement and quality 39 
assurance programs that help patients receiving clinically based services to accomplish 40 
their treatment goals during their approved term of treatment. 41 
COMMI TTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 634 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT Sec. TT-2.  Report.   The stakeholder group shall submit a report to the department 1 
and to the Joint Standing Committee on Health and Human Services with its findings and 2 
recommendations for changes, as identified pursuant to this Part, no later than December 3 
1, 2015.  Any changes to methadone treatment made by the department, pursuant to the 4 
proposed changes included in the stakeholder group's report, must take effect March 1, 5 
2016. 6

both MaineCare and Medicare Part D; 13

disabled by the standards of the federal social security program.  A person who 16 
was eligible for the program at any time from August 1, 1998 to July 31, 1999 17 
and who does not meet the requirements of this subparagraph at the time of 18 
application or renewal retains eligibility for the program if that person is a 19 
member of a household of an eligible person.; and 20

PART XX 13 
Sec. XX-1.  34-B MRSA §3011 is enacted to read: 14 
§3011.  Bridging Rental Assistance Program 15 
The Bridging Rental Assistance Program is established within the department as a 16 
transitional housing voucher program.  The purpose of the program is to assist persons 17 
with mental illness with housing assistance for up to 24 months or until they receive 18 
assistance from a housing voucher program administered by the United States 19 
Department of Housing and Urban Development under the United States Housing Act of 20 
1937, Public Law 412, Section 8 or receive an alternative housing placement.  The 21 
department shall adopt rules to carry out the purpose of the program.  Rules adopted 22 
pursuant to this section are routine technical rules as defined in Title 5, chapter 375, 23 
subchapter 2- A. 24

PART ZZ 34 
Sec. ZZ-1.  Study.  The Department of Transportation, in consultation with the 35 
cities of Lewiston and Auburn and the Northern New England Passenger Rail Authority, 36 
shall conduct a study and complete a plan for the implementation of passenger rail service 37 
COMMI TTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 636 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT between the cities of Lewiston and Auburn and the Amtrak Downeaster service.  The 1 
plan must include a process for public review and comment and must incorporate 2 
information from completed studies and new information, including, but not limited to: 3 
1.  An analysis of market demand and the potential economic benefits associated with 4 
the implementation of passenger rail service between the cities of Lewiston and Auburn 5 
and the Amtrak Downeaster service, and potential future expansion to Montreal; 6 
2.  The development of a detailed service plan to meet travel demand and identified 7 
economic opportunities, including frequency and schedule of service, station locations, 8 
equipment types and seating capacity, marketing, management and operator plans and 9 
estimated annual operating costs; 10 
3.  An inventory of infrastructure needed to support operations, including mechanical 11 
facilities, with an estimate of the necessary capital investments; 12 
4.  An evaluation of potential financing mechanisms for capital and operating 13 
expenses and an implementation approach and schedule; and 14 
5.  A review of potential alternatives and environmental impacts associated with the 15 
proposed service, including station locations and necessary investments. 16 
Sec. ZZ-2.  Transfer from unappropriated surplus of the General Fund.  17 
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the State Controller shall transfer $150,000 18 
no later than July 15, 2015 from the unappropriated surplus of the General Fund to the 19 
Multimodal - Passenger Rail program, Other Special Revenue Funds account in the 20 
Department of Transportation. 21 
Sec. ZZ-3.  Community match.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law, no 22 
later than November 1, 2015, the cities of Lewiston and Auburn each shall remit $50,000 23 
to the State for the purposes of funding the study and plan for the implementation of 24 
passenger rail service between the cities of Lewiston and Auburn and the Amtrak 25 
Downeaster service pursuant to section 1 of this Part.  The Treasurer of State shall deposit 26 
the funds in the Multimodal - Passenger Rail program, Other Special Revenue Fund s 27 
account in the Department of Transportation. 28

Sec. DDD-2.  20-A MRSA §6663 is enacted to read: 22 
§6663.  Commission To End Student Hunger 23

the following options: 34

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT (2)  One member from a statewide or regional organization dedicated to 1 
alleviating child hunger; 2 
(3)  One member from a statewide or regional organization that runs a food 3 
pantry; and 4 
(4)  One member who is a food service director in a municipality or school 5 
administrative unit that uses the United States Department of Agriculture 6 
community eligibility provision, as provided in 42 United States Code, Section 7 
1759a(a)(1)(F ); 8 
D.  Three public members appointed by the Speaker of the House, chosen from 3 of 9 
the following options: 10 
(1)  One member from a statewide or regional farm organization; 11 
(2)  One member from a statewide or regional organization that runs a school 12 
food program for students in at-risk areas; 13 
(3)  One member who is a superintendent of a school administrative unit; and 14 
(4)  One member who is an elected official in a municipality that participates in 15 
the United States Department of Agriculture community eligibility provision, as 16 
provided in 42 United States Code, Section 1759a(a)(1)(F); 17 
E.  One public member appointed by the Governor who is a parent of a child who has 18 
used or is using free or reduced-price student meal programs; 19 
F.  The commissioner or the commissioner's designee; and 20 
G.  The Commissioner of Health and Human Services or the commissioner's 21 
designee. 22 
2.  Chairs.  For the first 2 years of the commission, the Senate member is the Senate 23 
chair and the House of Representatives member is the House chair.  In subsequent years, 24 
the chair of the commission must be elected by the members of the commission at the 25 
first meeting of each year. 26 
3.  Appointments; vacancies; quorum.  A nonlegislative member of the 27 
commission must be appointed for a 2-year term.  A member may continue to serve until 28 
the member's replacement is appointed.  When a vacancy exists, the appointing authority 29 
shall appoint a new member from the same category as the member vacating the 30 
commission.  A quorum consists of 6 members. 31 
4.  Duties; funding.  The commission shall meet at least 2 and no more than 4 times 32 
per year. The commission shall work to implement the 5-year plan to end student hunger 33 
developed by the Task Force To End Student Hunger in Maine pursuant to Resolve 2013, 34 
chapter 107, shall monitor the plan and shall update it if necessary.  In addition, the 35 
commission may conduct public meetings throughout the State to highlight the issue of 36 
student hunger.  Every one or 2 years the commission may conduct a statewide summit of 37 
state leaders regarding ending student hunger.  The commission shall provide advice 38 
regarding the responsibilities of and supervision of the hunger coordinators in their 39 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 639 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT working across the State and performing the following functions within school 1 
administrative units and communities: 2 
A.  Compile and analyze data to identify opportunities to increase food security and 3 
the progress made in decreasing student hunger; 4 
B.  Raise awareness of food insecurity and of opportunities and best practices to 5 
decrease food insecurity; 6 
C.  Assist school board and school food service directors and community leaders in 7 
understanding, applying for and complying with the requirements of the child 8 
nutrition programs offered by the United States Department of Agriculture and 9 
understanding the effect of the programs on students, schools and communities; and 10 
D.  Report by November 15th each year to the commission on food insecurity in 11 
communities and school administrative units and the progress made in decreasing 12 
student hunger. 13 
5.  Staff assistance.  The department shall provide necessary staffing services to the 14 
commission. 15 
6.  Report; legislation.  By January 10th each year, the commission shall submit to 16 
the joint standing committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over education matters 17 
a report that includes findings and recommendations for action to eliminate student 18 
hunger.  The commission is authorized to submit to the Legislature legislation as the 19 
commission may determine to be appropriate. 20 
Sec. DDD-3.  Collaboration to reduce student hunger.  The Department of 21 
Education and the Department of Health and Human Services shall collaborate to reduce 22 
student hunger through the following actions. 23 
1.  Using new state funding and creating a new position, the Department of Education 24 
and the Department of Health and Human Services shall increase communication and 25 
cooperation between the 2 departments and the monitoring of child hunger and nutrition 26 
programs in both departments. Representatives of the departments shall meet quarterly t o 27 
collaborate on child hunger and nutrition programs.  The departments shall provide 28 
quarterly reports to the joint standing committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction 29 
over education matters and to the Commission To End Student Hunger, established in the 30 
Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 12004-I, subsection 12-B, on their quarterly 31 
meetings and on cooperation between the departments regarding child hunger and 32 
nutrition programs. 33 
2.  The Department of Education and the Department of Health and Human Services 34 
shall expand access to departmental data in order to measure and track access to and 35 
participation in child hunger and nutrition programs under the jurisdiction of both 36 
departments.  The departments shall provide each school administrative unit and school 37 
with analyses of its existing child hunger and nutrition programs and their funding and 38 
federal funding not being used.  The departments shall make student meal program data 39 
available on their publicly accessible websites. 40 
Sec. DDD-4.  Encouraging participation in federal meals and snacks 41 
programs for students.  The Department of Education and the Department of Health 42 
and Human Services shall encourage the congressional delegation of the State to make 43

administrative units and nonprofit organizations and to make administration of the 2

PART HHH 33 
Sec. HHH-1.  20-A MRSA c. 333 is enacted to read: 34 
CHAPTER 333 35 
COMMUNITY SCHOOLS 36 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 641 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT §9921.  Definitions 1 
As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following terms 2 
have the following meanings. 3 
1.  Community partner.  "Community partner" means a provider of one or more of 4 
the following services to students, families or community members: 5 
A.  Primary medical or dental care; 6 
B.  Nurse home visitation services; 7 
C.  Mental health treatment and counseling services; 8 
D.  Developmentally appropriate physical education activities; 9 
E.  Academic enrichment activities; 10 
F.  Specialized instructional support services; 11 
G.  Teacher home visits; 12 
H.  Programs designed to improve student attendance at school, including programs 13 
that provide assistance to students who are truant or who have been suspended or 14 
expelled; 15 
I.  Mentoring and other youth development programs, including peer mentoring and 16 
conflict mediation; 17 
J.  Community service and service-learning opportunities; 18 
K.  Early childhood education; 19 
L.  Programs that promote parental involvement and family literacy; 20 
M.  Parenting education activities; 21 
N.  Parenting leadership development activities; 22 
O.  Child care services; 23 
P.  Youth and adult job training, internship opportunities and career counseling 24 
services; 25 
Q.  Nutrition education; 26 
R.  Adult education, including instruction in English as a second language; 27 
S.  Remedial education and enrichment activities, including expanded learning time; 28 
T.  Summer or after-school enrichment and learning experiences; 29 
U.  Legal services; 30 
V.  Juvenile crime prevention and rehabilitation programs; 31 
W.  Homelessness prevention services; or 32 
X.  Any appropriate services and programs authorized by a community school that 33 
are consistent with the services and programs specified in paragraphs A to W. 34 
COMMI TTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 642 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT 2.  Community school.  "Community school" means a public elementary or 1 
secondary school that: 2 
A.  Participates in a community-based effort to coordinate and integrate educational, 3 
developmental, family, health and other comprehensive services through community- 4 
based organizations and public and private partnerships; and 5 
B.  Provides access to services under paragraph A to students, families and the 6 
community, such as access during the school year to services before school hours, 7 
after school hours and during the weekend, as well as access to such services during 8 
the summer. 9 
§9922.  Establishment of a community school 10 
Beginning October 1, 2015, a school board may designate an existing school or 11 
establish a new school as a community school. 12 
1.  Community school plan goals.    A community school shall collaborate with 13 
community partners to provide services to students, families and community members 14 
that promote student success while addressing the needs of the whole student.  A school 15 
board may designate or establish a community school as long as the community school 16 
plan developed by the school board is consistent with the following goals: 17 
A.  Improving student learning and development by providing support for students to 18 
enable them to graduate college-ready and career-ready; 19 
B.  Improving the coordination and integration, accessibility and effectiveness of 20 
services for children and families, particularly for students attending high-poverty 21 
schools, including high-poverty rural schools; 22 
C.  Enabling educators and school personnel to complement and enrich efforts to 23 
improve academic achievement and other results related to student learning and 24 
development; 25 
D.  Ensuring that children have the physical, social and emotional well-being to come 26 
to school ready to engage in the learning process every day; 27 
E.  Promoting and enabling family and community engagement in the education of 28 
children; 29 
F.  Enabling more efficient use of federal, state, local and private sector resources that 30 
serve children and families; 31 
G.  Facilitating the coordination and integration of programs and services operated by 32 
community-based organizations, nonprofit organizations and state, local and tribal 33 
governments; 34 
H.  Engaging students as resources for their communities; and 35 
I.  Engaging the business community and other community organizations as partners. 36 
2.  Audit.  Following the designation or establishment of a community school, but 37 
prior to the opening of a community school, a school board shall conduct: 38 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 643 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT A.  A community needs audit to identify the academic, physical, social, emotional, 1 
health, mental health and civic needs of students and their families that may affect 2 
student learning and academic achievement; 3 
B.  A community resource assessment of potential resources, services and 4 
opportunities available within or near the community that students, families and 5 
community members may access and integrate into the community school; and 6 
C.  For an existing school that has been designated as a community school, an 7 
operations and instructional audit. 8 
3.  Plan.  A school board shall develop a community school plan for each school 9 
designated or established as a community school. 10 
A.  When developing a community school plan for the establishment of a new 11 
community school, the school board shall use the results of the community resource 12 
assessment under subsection 2, paragraph B to address the specific needs identified in 13 
the community needs audit under subsection 2, paragraph A. 14 
B.  When developing a community school plan for the designation of an existing 15 
school as a community school, the school board shall use the results of the 16 
community resource assessment under subsection 2, paragraph B to address the 17 
specific needs identified in the community needs audit under subsection 2, paragraph 18 
A and the operations and instructional audit under subsection 2, paragraph C. 19 
C.  A community school plan must coordinate, integrate and enhance services for 20 
students, families and community members at the community school to improve the 21 
academic achievement of students and increase family and community involvement 22 
in education. 23 
D.  A community school plan must include cost estimates or an operational budget 24 
for the specified educational, developmental, family, health and other comprehensive 25 
services to be provided by the community school. 26 
E.  When developing a community school plan for the establishment of a new 27 
community school, a school board shall designate a community school coordinator to 28 
manage the partnerships with community partners participating in the community 29 
school plan. 30 
4.  Funding.  The commissioner may provide state funding to the school 31 
administrative units in which community schools are located pursuant to section 32 
15689-A, subsection 25.  In providing funds under this subsection, the commissioner 33 
shall give priority to a qualified school administrative unit in which at least 40% of the 34 
students are economically disadvantaged students as determined pursuant to section 35 
15675, subsection 2 and that has more economically disadvantaged students than other 36 
qualified school administrative units under this subsection. 37 
5.  Gifts, grants and donations.  A school administrative unit may seek and accept 38 
public and private gifts, grants and donations to offset the costs of developing and 39 
implementing a community school plan under subsection 3.  A gift, grant or donation 40 
received pursuant to this subsection must be approved by the school board prior to the 41 
receipt of the gift, grant or donation. 42 
COMMI TTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 644 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT §9923.  Pilot project for community schools 1 
The department is authorized to designate 3 community schools established in 2 
accordance with this chapter as part of a 5-year pilot project beginning in the 2016-2017 3 
school year.  The commissioner shall provide state funding to the school administrative 4 
units in which the designated community schools are located and may employ a state 5 
community school coordinator to implement this pilot project.  Annual state allocations 6 
for this pilot project may not exceed $150,000. 7 
This section is repealed July 1, 2021. 8

PART PPP 5 
Sec. PPP-1.  20 -A MRSA §6602, sub-§12, as enacted by PL 2001, c. 447, §1, is 6 
amended to read: 7 
12.  Local Produce Fund.   The Local Produce Fund is established within the 8 
Department of Education department.  The fund is authorized to receive revenue from 9 
public and private sources.  The fund must be held separate and apart from all other 10 
money, funds and accounts.  Any balance remaining in the fund at the end of the fiscal 11 
year must be carried forward to the next fiscal year.  The fund must be used to match $1 12 
for every $3 a school administrative unit pays for produce or minimally processed foods 13 
purchased directly from a farmer or,  farmers' cooperative or local food hub in the State, to 14 
a maximum state contribution of $1,000 or $2,000 if funding is received and the school 15 
administrative unit sends a food service employee to local foods training administered by 16 
the department under subsection 13.  At the end of the fiscal year, the school 17 
administrative unit may provide the department with receipts documenting purchases 18 
pursuant to this subsection during that year.  For purposes of this subsection, "minimally 19 
processed" means only the washing, cleaning, trimming, drying, sorting and packaging of 20 
food items or a combination of those activities.  Reimbursement or partial reimbursement 21 
to school administrative units may only be made up to the amount available in the fund.  22 
Failure to reimburse does not constitute an obligation on behalf of the State to a school 23 
administrative unit.  The department shall apply for federal grant funding to provide state 24 
contributions in excess of $1,000 pursuant to this subsection if applicable grant funding is 25 
available.  The department may accept grant funding from hospitals and other sources to 26 
provide state contributions in excess of $1,000 pursuant to this subsection. 27 
Sec. PPP-2.  20-A MRSA §6602, sub-§§13 to 15 are enacted to read: 28 
13.  Local foods training.  The department shall administer a program to encourage 29 
and expand the use of local foods in school food service programs. As used in this 30 
subsection, unless the context otherwise indicates, "local food" means food produced or 31 
harvested by a Maine food producer as defined by Title 7, section 212, subsection 2, and 32 
"food hub" means any business or organization that locates and obtains food from local 33 
growers and fisheries and is able to handle the logistics of supplying and delivering local 34 
foods to schools.  The program must: 35 
A.  Provide competitive grants for a training program to be conducted in up to 6 36 
regions to provide training throughout the State without cost for local school food 37 
service programs to encourage and expand the use of local foods in school food 38 
service programs.  The training program must emphasize practical training for food 39 
preparers, including creative and effective cooking skills using local fresh foods and 40 
local food procurement skills.  The training program must also inform participants 41 
about practical supply chain solutions, including local food hubs and cooperatives 42 
within and across each region of the State; 43 
COMMI TTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 648 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT B.  Foster collaboration between school food service programs throughout the State; 1 
C.  Facilitate and encourage the use of local food hubs; and 2 
D.  Provide guidance to schools in the use of local food products and the nutritional 3 
attributes of local foods and provide strategies for encouraging maximum knowledge 4 
and acceptance of the nutritional value of locally produced food by students and 5 
communities. 6 
The department shall apply for federal grant funding to implement this subsection.  The 7 
department may implement this subsection only if the department receives funding 8 
covering the costs of the program under this subsection. 9 
14.  Food service program personnel; position description.   The department shall 10 
develop and post a model position description for school food service program personnel 11 
on its publicly accessible website.  The position description must meet the federal 12 
guidelines established under the Nutrition Education and Training Program and Team 13 
Nutrition initiative of the National School Lunch Program under 7 Code of Federal 14 
Regulations, Part 210. 15 
15.  Food service recognition.   The department shall provide for the development of 16 
an annual competitive skill-oriented school food service recognition based on criteria 17 
developed by the department emphasizing creative and effective use of local food 18 
products to attract students to eat healthier meals and snacks and promoting community 19 
interest in good nutrition and other factors determined by the department. 20

§1215.  Mileage and compensation of jurors 24 
A juror is entitled to paid mileage at the rate of 15¢ per mile for travel expenses from 25 
the juror's residence to the place of holding court and return and, except that, beginning 26 
July 1, 2016, a juror is entitled to paid mileage at the rate established in Title 5, section 8.  27 
A juror is entitled to compensation at the rate of $10 $15 for each day of required 28 
attendance at sessions of the court. 29
