COMMITTEE AMENDMENT Sec. RRR-2.  36 MRSA §5217-D, sub-§1, ¶¶B-1 and D-1, as enacted by PL 1 
2013, c. 525, §15, are amended to read: 2 
B-1.  "Financial aid package" means financial aid obtained by a student after 3 
December 31, 2007 for attendance at an accredited Maine community college, 4 
college or university after December 31, 2007.  For purposes of a qualified individual 5 
claiming a credit under this section for tax years beginning on or after January 1, 6 
2013, the financial aid package may include financial aid obtained for up to 30 credit 7 
hours of course work at an accredited non-Maine community college, college or 8 
university earned prior to transfer to an accredited Maine community college, college 9 
or university, if the 30 credit hours were earned after December 31, 2007 and the 10 
transfer occurred after December 31, 2012.   For purposes of a qualified individual 11 
claiming a credit under this section for tax years beginning on or after January 1, 12 
2016, who is eligible for a credit under paragraph G, subparagraph (1), division (b), 13 
the financial aid package may include financial aid obtained by a student for 14 
attendance at an accredited non-Maine community college, college or university after 15 
December 31, 2007.  For purposes of a qualified individual claiming a credit under 16 
this section for tax years beginning on or after January 1, 2016, who is eligible for a 17 
credit under paragraph G, subparagraph (1), division (c), the financial aid package 18 
may include financial aid obtained by a student for attendance at an accredited Maine 19 
college or university after December 31, 2007.  For purposes of an employer claiming 20 
a credit under this section for tax years beginning on or after January 1, 2013, the 21 
financial aid package may include financial aid obtained by a qualified employee 22 
after December 31, 2007 for attendance at an accredited non-Maine community 23 
college, college or university after December 31, 2007.  The financial aid package 24 
may include private loans or less than the full amount of loans under federal 25 
programs, depending on the practices of the accredited Maine or non-Maine 26 
community college, college or university.  Loans are includable in the financial aid 27 
package only if entered into prior to July 1, 2023. 28 
D-1.  "Principal cap" means: 29 
(1)  For an individual graduating from an accredited Maine community college, 30 
college or university before January 1, 2015, the amount calculated by the State 31 
Tax Assessor under Title 20-A, section 12542, former subsection 2-A;  32 
(2)  For an individual obtaining a bachelor's degree and graduating from an 33 
accredited Maine community college, college or university on or after January 1, 34 
2015, the average in-state tuition and mandatory fees for attendance at the 35 
University of Maine System for the academic year ending during the calendar 36 
year prior to the year of graduation multiplied by 4; and 37 
(3)  For an individual obtaining an associate degree and graduating from an 38 
accredited Maine community college, college or university on or after January 1, 39

Community College System for the academic year ending during the calendar 41 
year prior to the year of graduation multiplied by 2.; and 42 
(4)  For an individual obtaining a graduate degree and graduating from an 43 
accredited Maine college or university, the average in-state tuition and mandatory 44

G.  "Qualified individual" means an individual, including the spouse filing a joint 5 
return with the individual under section 5221, who is eligible for the credit provided 6 
in this section.  An individual is eligible for the credit if the individual: 7 
(1)  Attended, and obtained an associate or a bachelor's degree from, an 8

PART BBBB 3 
Sec. BBBB-1.  20-A MRSA §12730 is enacted to read: 4 
§12730.  Put ME to Work Program 5 
1.  Establishment; purpose.  The Put ME to Work Program, referred to in this 6 
section as "the program," is established within the centers.  The program must facilitate 7 
the establishment of job training programs at postsecondary institutions of higher 8 
education in this State by working with private businesses and postsecondary institutions 9 
of higher education. 10 
2.  Job training programs; criteria.  The job training programs in the program must 11 
provide training to prepare workers for jobs in high-demand fields.  The centers shall 12 
work with private businesses to determine the demand for jobs and the skills needed for 13 
those jobs and with postsecondary institutions of higher education to determine the ability 14 
of those institutions to provide the appropriate education and training, including teaching 15 
faculty and any necessary infrastructure.  A qualified job training program must meet the 16 
following criteria: 17 
A.  Support of at least 50% of the start-up costs for the job training program must be 18 
provided by a business or group of businesses that chooses to participate in a job 19 
training program.  The support may be provided through funds or through an in-kind 20 
contribution, such as equipment or teaching faculty; 21 
B.  The job training program must provide education or training for employment in a 22 
trade or industry with a significant demand for skilled labor either statewide or in a 23 
region that has been identified by the Center for Workforce Research and Information 24 
within the Department of Labor as providing employment for high-compensation 25 
jobs or in an industry in which technology or work practices have significantly 26 
changed to require training to assist new workers to acquire needed skills or 27 
incumbent workers to remain current and competitive; 28 
C.  A person who successfully completes the job training program must be awarded a 29 
certificate, degree or similar credential that is universally recognized by the trade or 30 
industry that meets the requirements of paragraph B in which the person intends to 31 
seek employment; and 32 
D.  In order to participate, a business must agree to hire a person who successfully 33 
completes the job training program at a post-training wage that is at least $2.50 per 34 
hour more than the minimum hourly wage rate established in state law and to provide 35 
successful incumbent worker trainees with an increase in the hourly wage to meet or 36 
exceed the median wage for that occupation in the State as identified by the Center 37 
for Workforce Research and Information within the Department of Labor. 38 
3.  Financial aid; funding.  The centers shall make available needs-based 39 
scholarships, grants and other financial aid to persons participating in a qualified job 40 
training program.  If the job training program includes academic credit, the program may 41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 657 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT coordinate with the financial aid office of the sponsoring postsecondary education 1 
institution to deliver an award to an individual student; the award must be used to assist 2 
with all or partial unmet expenses for tuition, fees or books after any existing financial aid 3 
resources are used.  The centers may accept funding from private businesses and other 4 
interests for this purpose. 5 
4.  Rules.  The Board of Trustees of the Maine Community College System shall 6 
amend or adopt as necessary the centers’ operational p olicies and procedures in order to 7 
implement the provisions of this section.  In selecting a business for the program, the 8 
board of trustees shall consider: 9 
A.  Whether the business provides fringe benefits and what those fringe benefits are; 10 
B.  Economic impacts to the local or regional economy; 11 
C.  The ability of the business to leverage other resources both in the short term and 12 
the long term; 13 
D.  The record of the business in training individuals who have historically faced 14 
barriers to employment and individuals who are unemployed or underemployed; 15 
E.  Occupational outcomes of individuals who have been trained by the business; and 16 
F.  Factors determined appropriate by the board of trustees. 17 
Recruitment of prospective trainees and preliminary screening and testing for funded 18 
partnerships must be done in conjunction with the Department of Labor’s career centers, 19 
as well as with state job training providers, industry partners and other referring 20 
organizations as appropriate and consistent with the program. 21 
To be considered eligible for training under this program, applicants must meet the 22 
specific training program’s related academic and admissions standards.  Individuals that 23 
do not meet threshold academic standards may be referred to available community 24 
remediation services.  Individuals enrolled in the program must maintain satisfactory 25 
academic performance and meet all requirements in order to continue enrollment in the 26 
program. 27

PART DDDD 3 
Sec. DDDD-1.  5 MRSA §17704-B, as amended by PL 2009, c. 213, Pt. SSS, §2 4 
and c. 474, §18, is further amended to read: 5 
§17704-B.  Back contributions for certain days off without pay 6 
1.  Election.   If the retirement system determines at the time a member retires that the 7 
member's benefit would be increased as a result of the inclusion of compensation that 8 
would have been paid for days off without pay or for days worked for which the level of 9 
pay is reduced as the result of the freezing of merit pay and longevity pay in fiscal year 10 
2002-03, 2009-10 or,  2010-11 or 2012-13, or a combination thereof, as provided in 11 
section 17001, subsection 4, paragraph A, the retirement system shall advise the member 12 
of that result and shall allow the member to elect to have that compensation included in 13 
the calculation of the member's benefit and to make payments set forth in subsection 2. 14 
2.  Payment.   The amount that a member who makes the election permitted in 15 
subsection 1 must pay is the amount equal to the employee contribution that member 16 
would have made on compensation that would have been paid to that member on the days 17 
off without pay or for days worked for which the level of pay is reduced as the result of 18 
the freezing of merit pay and longevity pay during fiscal year 2002-03, 2009-10 or, 2010- 19 
11 or 2012-13, or a combination thereof, as provided in section 17001, subsection 4, 20 
paragraph A, plus interest at a rate, to be set by the board, not to exceed regular interest 21 
by 5 or more percentage points.  Interest must be computed beginning at the end of the 22 
year when those contributions or pick-up contributions would have been made to the date 23 
of payment.  If the member elects to make the payment, the retirement system shall 24 
withhold the required amount from the member's first retirement benefit check. 25 
3.  Benefit calculation.   If the member fails to make the election within 31 days of 26 
the notification provided under subsection 1, the retirement system shall calculate the 27 
member's retirement benefit without inclusion of the days off without pay and without 28 
inclusion of the compensation that otherwise would have been paid if the freezing of 29 
merit pay and longevity pay had not occurred during fiscal year 2002-03, 2009-10 or, 30 
2010-11 or 2012-13, or a combination thereof, as provided in section 17001, subsection 31 
4, paragraph A. 32

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT PART FFFF 1 
Sec. FFFF-1.  Vacancy report. The Department of Administrative and Financial 2 
Services, Bureau of the Budget shall review vacant positions, regardless of funding 3 
source.  The bureau shall submit a report on its findings to the Joint Standing Committee 4 
on Appropriations and Financial Affairs by September 30, 2015 with any 5 
recommendations for eliminating vacant positions.  The report must also be delivered to 6 
the Joint Standing Committee on Transportation if the report includes any positions that 7 
are partially or wholly funded by the Highway Fund or by internal service funds, 8 
enterprise funds or Other Special Revenue Funds accounts of the Department of 9 
Transportation, the Department of Public Safety or the Department of the Secretary of 10 
State. 11 
PART GGGG 12 
Sec. GGGG-1.  Distribution of assistant district attorney positions.  The 13 
Attorney General and the 8 district attorneys shall jointly develop a proposed policy on 14 
the distribution of assistant district attorney positions across all prosecutorial districts that 15 
is equitable to each district.  The Attorney General and the district attorneys shall jointly 16 
submit a written report to the Joint Standing Committee on Appropriations and Financial 17 
Affairs and the Joint Standing Committee on Judiciary by September 1, 2015.  The report 18 
must contain the proposed policy, a description of the process used to develop the 19 
proposed policy and any other information the Attorney General and the district attorneys 20 
believe is relevant.  The Joint Standing Committee on Judiciary may report out legislation 21 
related to the report to the Second Regular Session of the 127th Legislature. 22 
PART HHHH 23 
Sec. HHHH-1.  Commission established.   Notwithstanding Joint Rule 353, the 24 
Commission To Study the Public Reserved Lands Management Fund, referred to in this 25 
Part as "the commission," is established. 26 
Sec. HHHH-2.  Commission membership.   The commission consists of the 27 
following members: 28 
1.  Two members of the Senate, appointed by the President of the Senate, including 29 
one member from each of the 2 parties holding the largest number of seats in the 30 
Legislature; 31 
2.  Three members of the House of Representatives, appointed by the Speaker of the 32 
House, including at least one member from each of the 2 parties holding the largest 33 
number of seats in the Legislature; 34 
3.  Four members appointed by the President of the Senate as follows: 35 
A.  A commercial wood harvester; 36 
B.  A state-licensed forester; 37 
C.  A scientist who has studied forest health and management; and 38 
COMMI TTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 660 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT D.  A representative of the tourism industry; 1 
4.  Four members appointed by the Speaker of the House as follows: 2 
A.  A representative of a conservation organization; 3 
B.  An individual who represents outdoor recreation interests; 4 
C.  A representative of commercial timber holdings in the State; and 5 
D.  A representative of a sportsman's group; 6 
5.  The Commissioner of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry, or the 7 
commissioner's designee; and 8 
6.  The Director of the Bureau of Parks and Lands within the Department of 9 
Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry, or the director's designee. 10 
Sec. HHHH-3.  Chairs.   The first-named Senate member is the Senate chair and 11 
the first-named House of Representatives member is the House chair of the commission. 12 
Sec. H HHH -4.  Appointments; convening of commission.   All appointments 13 
must be made no later than 30 days following the effective date of this Part.  The 14 
appointing authorities shall notify the Executive Director of the Legislative Council once 15 
all appointments have been completed.  After appointment of all members, the chairs 16 
shall call and convene the first meeting of the commission within 45 days.  If 30 days or 17 
more after the effective date of this Part a majority of but not all appointments have been 18 
made, the chairs may request authority and the Legislative Council may grant authority 19 
for the commission to meet and conduct its business. 20 
Sec. HHHH-5.  Duties.   The commission shall meet a minimum of 4 times to 21 
review, study and analyze: 22 
1.  The proper use of the Public Reserved Lands Management Fund established in the 23 
Maine Revised Statutes, Title 12, section 1849 and its possible expansion to other uses; 24 
2.  The proper sustainable harvest levels on state land and how best to maintain those 25 
levels; 26 
3.  How best to manage public lands to preserve forests for recreation, wildlife habitat 27 
and public use while ensuring a healthy working forest; 28 
4.  After reviewing data and current science, how best to manage the State's public 29 
lands to deal with possible pest and disease issues; 30 
5.  Investments in public lands to increase access to public lands and spur rural 31 
economic development; 32 
6.  The impact of outdoor recreation on the State's tourism economy and the role 33 
public lands play in that economy; and 34 
7.  Any other issues the commission feels necessary to protect and manage public 35 
lands and the funds derived from those public lands. 36 
Sec. HHHH-6.  Staff assistance.  The Legislative Council shall provide 37 
necessary staffing services to the commission. 38

PART MMMM 21 
Sec. MMMM-1.  22 MRSA §1315, sub-§5 -C, as amended by PL 1995, c. 453, 22 
§5, is further amended to read: 23 
5-C.  Lead poisoning.   "Lead poisoning" means a confirmed elevated level of blood 24 
lead that is injurious, as defined in rules adopted by the department using intervention 25 
reference levels no higher than those set the 97.5th percentile of blood lead levels in 26 
children established by a national health and nutrition examination survey adopted by the 27 
federal Department of Health and Human Services, Centers for Disease Control and 28 
Prevention. 29 
Sec. MMMM-2.  22 MRSA §1325, as amended by PL 1999, c. 276, §17, is 30 
further amended to read: 31 
§1325.  Violation 32 
In addition to any other penalty imposed under this chapter, any person who violates 33 
any section of this chapter may be punished for each violation by a fine of not more than 34 
$500 or by imprisonment for not more than 6 months, or by both.   A person who violates 35 
any section of this chapter or rules adopted pursuant to this chapter commits a Class E 36 
crime.  In addition, other than for a violation covered under section 1316-A, the 37 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 663 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT department may, in accordance with Title 5, chapter 375, subchapter 4, impose an 1 
administrative penalty not to exceed $500 for a violation of this chapter or rules adopted 2 
pursuant to this chapter.  Each day a violation continues constitutes a separate offense.  3 
Violations existing within individual dwelling units are considered separate violations.  4 
An action commenced by the department to enforce any administrative penalty imposed 5 
under this section may be brought in the name of the State in the Superior Court in the 6 
county where the violation occurred or in Kennebec County and must be prosecuted by 7 
the Attorney General.  The court shall award to the State all costs in bringing the 8 
enforcement action as well as reasonable interest on penalties not paid.   This section does 9 
not limit the authority of the Department of Environmental Protection to seek penalties 10 
for violations under the authority of Title 38, section 349.  All penalties and awards 11 
collected under this section must be deposited in the Lead Poisoning Prevention Fund 12 
established under section 1322- E. 13 
Sec. MMMM-3.  22 MRSA §1326, as amended by PL 2005, c. 530, §5, is further 14 
amended to read: 15 
§1326.  Injunction requiring removal 16 
If the lead-based substance remains an environmental lead hazard at the expiration of 17 
30 days or at the expiration of an extension given by the commissioner pursuant to 18 
section 1321, that is a violation of this chapter and the State, in addition to any other 19 
remedies it has, may seek a mandatory injunction ordering the environmental lead hazard 20 
removed by a suitable 3rd party at the expense of the owner of the dwelling, premises, 21 
residential child-occupied facility, child care facility, premises of the family child care 22 
provider or nursery school. 23

vehicles in its rental fleet registered in the State.  All fees must be disclosed when an 33

COMMI TTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 666 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT PART SSSS 1 
Sec. SSSS-1.  Affordable housing working group.   The director of the Maine 2 
State Housing Authority, referred to in this Part as "the director," or the director's 3 
designee shall convene a working group to evaluate the extent to which extremely low- 4 
income households, including families, persons with disabilities and elderly persons, lack 5 
access to safe and affordable housing and the burden that this inadequacy creates for 6 
individuals and communities.  "Extremely low-income households" mean those with 7 
incomes at or below 30% of the area median income for their county or metropolitan 8 
area.  9 
The director or the director's designee shall convene the first meeting of the working 10 
group no later than September 15, 2015. 11 
1.  Members.  The working group consists of 9 voting members. 12 
The director, or the director's designee, serves as a voting member of the working group. 13 
The director shall appoint the following 8 additional voting members: 14 
A.  The director of the office for family independence within the Department of 15 
Health and Human Services or a designee; 16 
B.  One member of a statewide organization representing Maine municipal welfare 17 
directors; 18 
C.  One member representing a nonprofit developer of affordable housing; 19 
D.  One member representing an advocacy organization representing the interests of 20 
people with low income expertise in policy and legal matters related to public benefit 21 
programs; 22 
E.  One member representing a local housing authority; 23 
F.  One member representing a nonprofit homeless service provider; 24 
G.  One member with extremely low income who has experienced housing 25 
inadequacy; and 26 
H.  One member representing a community action agency. 27 
The working group may create subgroups to work on specific issues or initiatives and 28 
may include individuals who are not working group members.  29 
2.  Dutie s. The working group shall make recommendations to the director.  In 30 
developing its recommendations under this subsection, the working group shall: 31 
A.  Review existing data, reports and other materials describing the extent to which 32 
Maine people with extremely low incomes lack access to safe and affordable housing, 33 
including data related to waiting lists for the United States Department of Housing 34 
and Urban Development's housing choice voucher program. 35 
B.  Assess the burden that lack of affordable housing places on municipal general 36 
assistance programs and other community resources; 37 
C.  Review the role of the Maine State Housing Authority in providing housing 38 
assistance to households with extremely low incomes; 39 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 667 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT D.  Examine strategies employed by other states to improve access to affordable 1 
housing for extremely low-income people and determine best practices among those 2 
states; 3 
E.  Evaluate resources and strategies available to the Maine State Housing Authority 4 
to increase access to safe and affordable housing for extremely low-income 5 
households, including strategies to transition families or individuals from shelters to 6 
permanent housing, to address the needs of families at risk of homelessness that must 7 
rely on support from municipal general assistance programs and to assist families 8 
facing housing instability due to high housing cost burdens; and 9 
F.  Examine all state-administered housing voucher programs to determine if they are 10 
being administered in an efficacious manner through the most appropriate state 11 
agency. 12 
3.  Report.   The working group shall prepare a report based on its findings under 13 
subsection 2.  No later than December 1, 2015, the director of the Maine State Housing 14 
Authority shall submit the report and recommendations developed pursuant to subsection 15 
2, including any suggested legislation, to the Joint Standing Committee on 16 
Appropriations and Financial Affairs and the Joint Standing Committee on Labor, 17 
Commerce, Research and Economic Development. The Joint Standing Committee on 18 
Labor, Commerce, Research and Economic Development may report out a bill to 19 
implement the recommendations.  20 
Emergency clause.  In view of the emergency cited in the preamble, this 21 
legislation takes effect when approved, except as otherwise indicated. '  22 
SUMMARY 23 
PART A 24 
 25 
This Part makes appropriations and allocations of funds for the 2016-2017 biennium. 26 
PART B 27 
 28 
This Part makes appropriations and allocations of funds for approved reclassifications 29 
and range changes. 30 
PART C 31 
 32 
This Part establishes the total cost of education from kindergarten to grade 12 for 33 
fiscal year 2015-16, the state contribution and the annual target state share percentage.  34 
This Part also delays until fiscal year 2017-18 a requirement that $4,000,000 in revenue 35 
from casinos provide start-up funds for public preschool programs.  This Part authorizes 36 
the Commissioner of Education to expend and disburse funds to support school 37 
improvement activities, enhancements to career and technical education programs and 38 
performance evaluation and professional growth systems.  This Part requires the 39 
Commissioner of Education to expend and disburse $75,000 in fiscal year 2015-16 and 40 
$75,000 in fiscal year 2016-17 for the College for ME - Androscoggin program.  This 41 
COMMI TTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 668 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT Part also directs the Department of Education to review certain essential programs and 1 
services components. 2 
PART D 3 
 4 
This Part repeals the requirement that the Commissioner of Public Safety and the 5 
Attorney General pursue federal funding to establish a cold case homicide unit.  This Part 6 
also repeals the provision of law that makes establishment of a cold case homicide unit 7 
contingent upon availability of federal funding.  The provision of law directing the 8 
Attorney General in collaboration with the Commissioner of Public Safety to establish a 9 
cold case homicide unit is not repealed. 10 
PART E 11 
 12 
This Part requires $500,000 to be transferred from the General Fund undedicated 13 
revenue to the Maine Clean Election Fund on or before July 15, 2016 and the remaining 14 
$1,500,000 of the required annual transfer to be made on or before January 1, 2017. 15 
Current law requires $2,000,000 to be transferred annually on or before January 1st. 16 
PART F 17 
 18 
This Part amends the laws governing disclosures made by lobbyists by: 19 
1.  Permitting a lobbyist to notify the Commission on Governmental Ethics and 20 
Election Practices of the termination of a lobbying relationship rather than requiring 21 
notice by the lobbyist's employer; 22 
2.  Removing the requirement that state employees must sign annual registration 23 
forms in order to facilitate electronic submission of registrations; and 24 
3.  Requiring the commission to deposit the entire registration fee paid by lobbyists 25 
and lobbyist associates into a special revenue account to be spent on administrative and 26 
technology costs to facilitate disclosure of lobbying and campaign finance information to 27 
the public. 28 
PART G 29 
 30 
This Part directs the Judicial Department to conduct or contract for architectural 31 
feasibility studies to improve court facilities in Oxford County, Waldo County and York 32 
County and report to the joint standing committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction 33 
over appropriations and financial affairs and the joint standing committee of the 34 
Legislature having jurisdiction over judiciary matters by January 1, 2017. 35 
PART H 36 
 37 
This Part provides for an interfund advance of $37,000,000 from Other Special 38 
Revenue Funds to the General Fund unappropriated surplus required for one day at the 39 
end of fiscal year 2015-16. 40 
PART I 41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 669 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  1 
This Part reduces funding for debt service. 2 
PART J 3 
 4 
This Part provides that, for estates of decedents dying on or after January 1, 2016, the 5 
amount excluded from the Maine estate tax is the same as the applicable federal exclusion 6 
amount, which is indexed annually for inflation. 7 
PART K 8 
 9 
This Part increases the homestead property tax exemption from $10,000 to $15,000 10 
for property tax years beginning on or after April 1, 2016 and requires the State to 11 
reimburse municipalities for 100% for the property tax loss attributable to the increase in 12 
the first 2 years and 75% of the property tax loss in subsequent years. 13 
PART L 14 
 15 
This Part does the following. 16 
1.  It adjusts municipal revenue sharing for fiscal years 2015-16 and 2016-17 to set a 17 
fixed level of total revenue sharing transfers of $62,500,000, which is approximately the 18 
current projected level for fiscal year 2014-15. 19 
2.  It allows the State Controller to make adjustments for the actual monthly 20 
calculation of municipal revenue sharing in fiscal years 2015-16 and 2016-17 to provide 21 
for appropriate transfers back to the General Fund, keeping the revenue sharing transfers 22 
to municipalities fixed. 23 
PART M 24 
 25 
This Part does the following: 26 
1.  Changes the distribution of available balances in the unappropriated surplus of the 27 
General Fund.  In addition to the fixed transfer replenishing the State Contingent Account 28 
up to $350,000 and the fixed transfer for the Loan Insurance Reserve up to an amount of 29 
$1,000,000, this Part establishes a fixed transfer for the Reserve for General Fund 30 
Operating Capital of $2,500,000 and a transfer for the Retiree Health Insurance Internal 31 
Service Fund up to an amount of $4,000,000 over the 2016-2017 biennium and up to an 32 
amount of $2,000,000 thereafter; 33 
2.  Changes the growth limitation factor in the laws governing limits on government 34 
spending to the 10-year average of nominal personal income growth.  It eliminates the 35 
use of the 10-year average of population growth and inflation in determining the growth 36 
limitation factor plus the property growth factor; 37 
3.  Sets the biennial base year appropriation to the appropriation for the 2018-2019 38 
biennium enacted for fiscal year 2016-17 as of December 1, 2016; 39 
COMMI TTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 670 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT 4.  Eliminates all language dealing with the calculation of the state and local tax 1 
burden and how the growth limitation factor changes depending on how the state and 2 
local tax burden of this State compares to that of other states; and 3 
5.  Raises the limit on the balance in the Maine Budget Stabilization Fund from 12% 4 
of total General Fund revenues in the immediately preceding state fiscal year to 18%. 5 
PART N 6 
 7 
This Part authorizes new Maine Governmental Facilities Authority borrowing of 8 
$23,000,000 to provide funding for capital repairs and improvements to state facilities. 9 
PART O 10 
 11 
This Part reduces the amount of funding transferred from the real estate transfer tax 12 
to the Maine State Housing Authority in fiscal years 2015-16 and 2016-17 by increasing 13 
the amount transferred to the General Fund by $6,291,740 in fiscal year 2015-16 and by 14 
$6,090,367 in fiscal year 2016-17. 15 
PART P 16 
 17 
This Part continues authorization for each individual tax expenditure provided by 18 
statute. 19 
PART Q 20 
 21 
This Part establishes an attrition rate of 3% for the 2016-2017 biennium for all 22 
judicial branch and executive branch departments and agencies, except that the attrition 23 
rate for the District Attorneys Salaries program is set at 0% for the 2016-2017 biennium.  24 
It also directs the State Budget Officer to consider the size of an agency when developing 25 
budgeted attrition savings.  It provides agencies with 50 or fewer legislatively authorized 26 
positions an opportunity to justify any deviation from the established savings target to the 27 
State Budget Officer. It authorizes the State Budget Officer to reassign the unrealized 28 
attrition savings from smaller agencies to other agencies.  It also prohibits an agency’s 29 
ability to achieve attrition savings in one fiscal year from having any effect on another 30 
fiscal year's attrition savings target.  It requires the State Budget Officer to calculate and 31 
transfer the savings resulting from the increased attrition rate. 32 
PART R 33 
 34 
This Part authorizes the Department of Administrative and Financial Services to enter 35 
into financing arrangements in fiscal years 2015-16 and 2016-17 for the acquisition of 36 
motor vehicles for the Central Fleet Management Division. 37 
PART S 38 
 39 
This Part authorizes the Department of Administrative and Financial Services to enter 40 
into financing arrangements in fiscal years 2015-16 and 2016-17 for the acquisition of 41 
motor vehicles for the State Police. 42 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 671 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT PART T 1 
 2 
This Part continues the voluntary employee incentive program for state employees 3 
through the 2016-2017 biennium. 4 
PART U 5 
 6 
This Part requires the State Controller to transfer $750,000 in each fiscal year of the 7 
2016-2017 biennium from the General Fund unappropriated surplus to the Fund for 8 
Efficient Delivery of Local and Regional Services - Administration, Other Special 9 
Revenue Funds account within the Department of Administrative and Financial Services. 10 
PART V 11 
 12 
This Part provides that the Director of the Division of Quality Assurance and 13 
Regulation and the Director of the Division of Animal and Plant Health, both within the 14 
Department of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry, are no longer subject to 15 
appointment by the Commissioner of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry. 16 
PART W 17 
 18 
This Part extends the requirement that the Commissioner of Corrections, or the 19 
commissioner’s designee, assume the duties of the State Board of Corrections from July 20 
1, 2015 to July 1, 2016.  This Part also requires the Commissioner of Corrections or the 21 
commissioner’s designee to distribut e fiscal year 2015-16 payments to support county jail 22 
operations. 23 
PART X 24 
 25 
This Part transfers $700,000 in fiscal year 2015-16 from the Dirigo Health Fund to 26 
the unappropriated surplus of the General Fund. 27 
PART Y 28 
 29 
This Part clarifies the powers and duties of the Director of the Bureau of Parks and 30 
Lands within the Department of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry. 31 
PART Z 32 
 33 
This Part provides emergency rule-making authority necessary to implement a rate 34 
increase for assigned counsel and contract counsel. 35 
PART AA 36 
 37 
This Part requires the Director of the Bureau of Forestry within the Department of 38 
Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry to appoint no fewer than 45 and no more than 50 39 
Forest Ranger II positions, subject to the Civil Service Law.  Additionally, the director is 40 
required to appoint no fewer than 17 forest rangers classified as follows: 3 Regional 41 
COMMI TTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 672 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT Rangers, 8 District Rangers, one Forest Fire Prevention Specialist, one Ranger Pilot 1 
Supervisor and 4 Ranger Pilots.  It also adds additional forest ranger duties. 2 
It also repeals 2 provisions of Public Law 1999, chapter 352 that require the 3 
Commissioner of Conservation to sell all bullet-proof vests, firearms and related 4 
equipment and that prohibit the commissioner from purchasing bullet-proof vests, 5 
firearms or related equipment without specific authorization by the Legislature. 6 
PART BB 7 
 8 
This Part requires the Department of Health and Human Services to contract with a 9 
3rd party to conduct a rate study of medication management services and outpatient 10 
services under Rule Chapter 101: MaineCare Benefits Manual, Section 65: Behavioral 11 
Health Services and all services in Section 28: Rehabilitative and Community Support 12 
Services for Children with Cognitive Impairments and Functional Limitations.  The 13 
department is required to provide a report no later than January 1, 2016 to the Joint 14 
Standing Committee on Health and Human Services with findings and recommendations 15 
for changes to the rates studied. 16 
PART CC 17 
 18 
This Part requires the State Budget Officer to calculate the unused balance of General 19 
Fund All Other appropriations to the Drug Enforcement Agency program within the 20 
Department of Public Safety savings resulting from not expending the funds for the 21 
purpose of processing crime scenes involving the seizure of methamphetamine 22 
laboratories and transfer those funds to the unappropriated surplus of the General Fund no 23 
later than June 30th of each year of the biennium.  This Part also requires the State 24 
Budget Officer to calculate the unused balance of General Fund All Other appropriations 25 
to the Remediation and Waste Management program within the Department of 26 
Environmental Protection related to the transfer of one Oil and Hazardous Material 27 
Responder I position and one Oil and Hazardous Material Responder II position an d 28 
related All Other from Other Special Revenue Funds to the General Fund that are not 29 
used for cleanup of illegal drug operations or natural gas contamination and transfer those 30 
funds to the unappropriated surplus of the General Fund no later than June 30th of each 31 
year of the biennium. 32 
PART DD 33 
 34 
This Part limits to agents or representatives of the Bureau of Forestry within the 35 
Department of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry who do not carry a firearm the 36 
exemption from the Maine Criminal Justice Academy training standards and law 37 
enforcement agency policy requirements under the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 25, 38 
chapter 341. 39 
PART EE 40 
 41 
This Part provides an income tax exemption for benefits received under a military 42 
retirement plan up to $25,000 for tax years beginning on or after January 1, 2016. 43 
PART FF 44 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 673 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  1 
This Part authorizes a one-time transfer of all funds in excess of $500,000 from 2 
unencumbered balance forward in the Personal Services line category in the Department 3 
of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry, Division of Forest Protection, General Fund 4 
account to the Capital Expenditures line category in the Division of Forest Protection, 5 
General Fund account to fund the overhaul of helicopters owned by the State. 6 
PART GG 7 
 8 
This Part limits timber harvesting on public reserved lands and nonreserved public 9 
lands to an average of 160,000 cords per year over any 3-year period.  It allows the 10 
Department of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry by rule, based on an independent 11 
timber inventory conducted after July 1, 2015, to establish a different sustainable harvest 12 
level.  The rules are major substantive rules and must be reviewed by the joint standing 13 
committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over public reserved and nonreserved 14 
lands matters. 15 
PART HH 16 
 17 
This Part transfers the sexual assault forensic examiner training program from the 18 
Department of the Attorney General to the Department of Health and Human Services.  19 
PART II 20 
 21 
This Part authorizes the Department of Corrections to transfer, by financial order 22 
upon the recommendation of the State Budget Officer and the approval of the Governor, 23 
Personal Services, All Other and Capital Expenditures funding between accounts within 24 
the same fund for the purpose of paying departmental overtime expenses for the 2016- 25 
2017 biennium. 26 
PART JJ 27 
 28 
This Part provides that if an applicant for general assistance under Title 22, chapter 29 
1161 has been released from a correctional facility within 45 days of application, the 30 
municipality of responsibility for the first 12 months of benefits is the municipality that 31 
was on record as the residence of the applicant when the applicant was committed to the 32 
correctional facility.  It requires that a responsible municipality accept applications by 33 
telephone as long as the call is being made from a municipal office and the written 34 
application is contemporaneously faxed or sent electronically to the municipality of 35 
responsibility. 36 
PART KK 37 
 38

organizational structure of the Department of Corrections to improve organizational 40 
efficiency and authorizes the State Budget Officer to transfer positions and available 41 
balances based on the review by financial order. The ability to make these transfers as an 42 
adjustment to position count or appropriations is limited to the period of July 1st to 43

 16

PART OO 20 
 21 
This Part: 22 
1.  Removes the Chief Academic Officer and Director, Special Services Team 23 
positions from the list of major policy-influencing positions within the Department of 24 
Education. These unclassified positions are reclassified in Part A, each to a Public 25 
Service Executive II position, classified positions within the department. These 26 
reclassifications reflect the level of responsibility and function of similar classifications 27 
within the department. 28 
2.  Removes the Chief Academic Officer and Director, Special Services Team 29 
positions in the list of the Commissioner of Education's appointments within the 30 
department.  This Part also eliminates the Deputy Chief of Staff position and creates a 31 
Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics Workforce Coordinator position in 32 
the list of the Commissioner of Education's appointments within the department. 33 
PART PP 34 
 35 
This Part authorizes the Department of Education to purchase portable computer 36 
devices for students and educators in fiscal years 2015-16 and 2016-17. 37

 39

2016-2017 biennium, as a one-time transfer, from the General Fund unappropriated 41

PART RR 3 
 4 
This Part renames the PK-20, Adult Education and Federal Programs Team program 5 
within the Department of Education the Learning Systems Team program. 6 
PART SS 7 
 8 
This Part aligns and standardizes the statutory range of licensing fees for adult and 9 
children's residential drug treatment centers, children's residential care facilities and 10 
mental health services facilities. The exact fees must be established by rule by the 11 
Department of Health and Human Services. 12 
This Part also standardizes the terms of these licenses at 2 years. 13 
PART TT 14 
 15 
This Part creates a stakeholder group, including representatives of patients and 16 
outpatient methadone treatment providers, to review criteria for receiving treatment, prior 17 
approvals and treatment service options for patients seeking methadone treatment 18 
services and requires the stakeholder group to provide a report with findings and 19 
recommendations to the Joint Standing Committee on Health and Human Services by 20 
December 1, 2015. It also provides that any changes made by the department pursuant to 21 
the proposed changes included in the stakeholder group's report must take effect March 1, 22 
2016. 23 
PART UU 24 
 25 
This Part includes a liquid asset test of no more than $50,000 per person or $75,000 26 
per couple in eligibility determinations for the elderly low cost drug program.  This is the 27 
same asset test used for the Medicare savings program. 28 
PART VV 29 
 30 
This Part gives the Department of Health and Human Services the authority to adopt 31 
emergency rules to implement any provisions of this Act over which it has specific 32 
authority that has not been addressed by some other Part of the Act without the necessity 33 
of demonstrating that immediate adoption is necessary to avoid a threat to public health, 34 
safety or welfare. 35 
PART WW 36 
 37 
This Part allows remaining balances at the end of each fiscal year in the Consumer- 38 
directed Services program and the Bridging Rental Assistance Program, General Fund 39 
accounts in the Department of Health and Human Services to be carried forward for use 40 
by those programs in the next fiscal year. 41 
PART XX 42

 13

 35

PART DDD 4 
 5 
This Part implements the recommendations of the Task Force To End Student 6 
Hunger in Maine as follows. 7 
1.  It establishes the Commission To End Student Hunger, an ongoing commission of 8 
11 appointed members, which is directed to work to implement a 5-year plan to end 9 
student hunger, is authorized to conduct a statewide summit of state leaders to end 10 
student hunger and is required to advise 4 hunger coordinators who will assist in 11 
implementing the 5-year plan. 12 
2.  It requires the Department of Education and the Department of Health and Human 13 
Services to meet quarterly to collaborate on child hunger and nutrition programs.  The 2 14 
departments are required to provide quarterly reports to the joint standing committee of 15 
the Legislature having jurisdiction over education matters and to the Commission To End 16 
Student Hunger.  It requires the 2 departments to expand access to departmental data and 17 
to provide each school administrative unit and school with analyses of its existing child 18 
nutrition programs and their funding and federal funding not being used.   19 
3.  It requires child nutrition data to be publicly available on the websites of the 20 
Department of Education and the Department of Health and Human Services. 21 
4.  It requires the Department of Education to establish a grant program to assist 22 
schools and school administrative units in ending student hunger. 23 
5.  It requires the Department of Education and the Department of Health and Human 24 
Services to encourage the congressional delegation of the State to make participation in 25 
federal meals and snacks programs for students easier for school administrative units and 26 
nonprofit organizations and to make administration of the programs easier for the 27 
departments. 28 
PART EEE 29 
 30 
This Part authorizes the Department of Health and Human Services to transfer family 31 
support services funds in the Developmental Services - Community program to the Office 32 
of Aging and Disability Services Central Office program and the Long Term Care - 33 
Office of Aging and Disability Services program by financial order. 34

PART HHH 4 
 5 
This Part authorizes a school board to designate an existing school or establish a new 6 
school to be a community school that participates with community partners to provide 7 
various educational and social services to students, families and community members.  8 
This Part provides the steps a school board must complete in order to establish a new 9 
community school, including conducting a community needs audit, conducting a 10 
community resource assessment and developing a community school plan, and requires 11 
that a school board that designates an existing school as a community school must also 12 
conduct a school operations and instructional audit. 13 
This Part also authorizes the Department of Education to provide funding to support 14 
the implementation of 3 community schools. 15

 17

and Human Services from range 38 to range 90. 19

for residents in rural and underserved communities.  This funding is targeted to support 35 
the provision of primary care services for the uninsured and underinsured, as well as to 36

PART OOO 14 
 15 
This Part amends the Fiscal Stability Program established to support the fish and 16 
wildlife conservation programs of the Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife so that 17 
it begins in the 2018-2019 biennium. 18 
PART PPP 19 
 20 
This Part requires the Department of Education to develop and support local food 21 
training programs for public school food service personnel and facilitate the use of local 22 
food hubs to expand the use of local foods in schools.  A local food hub is any business or 23 
organization that locates and obtains food from local growers and fisheries and is able to 24 
handle the logistics of supplying and delivering local foods to schools.  It increases the 25 
limit on the amount that the State matches for the acquisition of local food by a school 26 
administrative unit if the unit sends a food service employee for training in the acquisition 27 
and use of local foods.  It directs the department to develop and post a position 28 
description for school food service program personnel on its publicly accessible website 29 
and to develop an annual competitive skill-oriented school food service recognition 30 
emphasizing creative and effective use of local foods.  It directs the Department of 31 
Education to apply for federal grant funding for the implementation of the local foods 32 
training program and the increased state contribution for the Local Produce Fund and it 33 
makes implementation contingent on receipt of funding.  It also allows the department to 34 
accept grant funding from hospitals and other sources. 35 
PART QQQ 36 
 37 
This Part, beginning July 1, 2016, ties the mileage rate paid to jurors to the rate paid 38 
by the State to state employees who use their vehicles for state business.  This Part also 39 
increases the daily rate paid to jurors from $10 per day to $15 per day. 40 
PART RRR 41 
 42 
This Part makes changes to the educational opportunity tax credit. 43 
COMMI TTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 680 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT Under existing law, an individual graduating with an associate or bachelor's degree 1 
from an accredited Maine community college, college or university after December 31, 2 
2007 is eligible for a tax credit based on loan payments that are part of the individual's 3 
financial aid package.  This Part expands eligibility for such a tax credit to individuals 4 
graduating after December 31, 2007 with an associate or bachelor's degree from a non- 5 
Maine school and to individuals graduating with a graduate degree from a Maine school, 6 
but it specifies that a credit claimed under this expanded eligibility may be claimed only 7 
on returns filed for tax years beginning on or after January 1, 2016. 8 
PART SSS 9 
 10 
This Part authorizes a range change from salary range 88 to salary range 90 for the 11 
Securities Administrator within the Office of Securities in the Department of Professional 12 
and Financial Regulation. 13 
PART TTT 14 
 15 
This Part amends the law to require that fees for criminal history record checks for 16 
school employees be deposited in an account of the Department of Public Safety rather 17 
than the Department of Education. 18 
This Part provides that the full fee for fingerprint-supported criminal history record 19 
checks charged must be deposited in an Other Special Revenue Funds account for the 20 
purpose of paying the costs of the Department of Public Safety to administer the criminal 21 
history record checks for the Department of Education. 22 
This Part requires that fees associated with criminal history record check 23 
requirements established after July 1, 2015 be deposited in a dedicated revenue account to 24 
pay the costs of the Department of Public Safety, State Bureau of Identification to 25 
conduct such checks. 26 
This Part transfers the cash balance of the Criminal History Record Check Fund, 27 
projected at approximately $500,000, from the Department of Education to the 28 
Department of Public Safety. 29

 31

the carried funds to be transferred by financial order to the All Other line category in the 34 
same program. 35

 21

Financial Services, Information Services program, General Fund account must be carried 23 
forward in the 2016-2017 biennium. 24 
PART BBBB 25 
 26 
This Part establishes the Put ME to Work Program in the Maine Quality Centers to 27 
facilitate the establishment of job training programs at postsecondary institutions of 28 
higher education in this State by working with private businesses and postsecondary 29 
institutions of higher education to provide training to prepare workers for jobs in high- 30 
demand fields.  In order to participate in the program, a business or group of businesses is 31 
required to provide at least 50% of the cost of the program, which may be through in-kind 32 
contributions. 33 
This Part directs the Board of Trustees of the Maine Community College System to 34 
adopt necessary policies and procedures for the Maine Quality Centers, including 35 
consideration of at least 5 specific factors.  It also requires program participants to use 36 
existing financial aid resources available through their sponsoring postsecondary 37 
education institution before using program resources, which may be used only for unmet 38 
expenses for tuition, fees or books. 39 
Additionally, this Part requires participating employers under the Put ME to Work 40 
Program to hire successful trainees at a rate of at least $2.50 per hour more than the 41 
minimum hourly wage rate as set in Maine statute and to pay incumbent worker trainees 42 
COMMI TTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 682 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT an hourly wage that meets or exceeds the median wage for that occupation as identified 1 
by the Center for Workforce Research and Information within the Department of Labor. 2 
PART CCCC 3 
 4 
This Part exempts from the motor vehicle excise tax adaptive equipment installed on 5 
a motor vehicle owned by a carrier engaged in furnishing passenger service for hire. It 6 
also reduces by half the motor vehicle registration fee of a passenger vehicle used for hire 7 
that is equipped with adaptive equipment to make that vehicle operable or accessible by a 8 
person with a disability. 9 
PART DDDD 10 
 11 
This Part provides that the average annual rate of earnable compensation of a member 12 
of the Maine Public Employees Retirement System during the 3 years of creditable 13 
service as an employee in Maine, not necessarily consecutive, in which the member's 14 
annual rate of earnable compensation is highest must be determined as if the member had 15 
not been provided days off without pay or with reduced pay during fiscal year 2012-13 if 16 
the member elects to make a payment equal to the employee contribution that member 17 
would have made on compensation that would have been paid to that member on the days 18 
off without pay or at reduced pay. 19 
PART EEEE 20 
 21

year ending June 30, 2016 and in the fiscal year ending June 30, 2017 from the Salary 23 
Plan program, General Fund account in the Department of Administrative and Financial 24 
Services to programs within the Department of Corrections to implement wage 25 
adjustments to aid in the recruitment and retention of employees and to provide parity 26 
between state correctional employees and county or regional jail employees who perform 27 
similar direct care or supervision of prisoners. 28 
PART FFFF 29 
 30

of the Budget to review vacant positions and submit a report to the Joint Standing 32 
Committee on Appropriations and Financial Affairs with recommendations on 33

accounts of the Department of Transportation, the Department of Public Safety or the 37 
Department of the Secretary of State. 38

PART HHHH 5 
 6 
This Part establishes the Commission To Study the Public Reserved Lands 7 
Management Fund.  The commission is charged with, among other duties, reviewing and 8 
analyzing the proper use of the Public Reserved Lands Management Fund, proper 9 
sustainable harvest levels on state lands and possible investments in public lands to 10 
increase access to public lands and spur rural economic development. 11

 13 
This Part renames the Land and Water Quality program the Water Quality program 14 
and establishes the Land Resources program within the Department of Environmental 15 
Protection. 16

 18

and employees and the law establishing certain positions as major policy-influencing 20 
positions in the Department of Environmental Protection, the position of Director of the 21 
Bureau of Land and Water Quality to Director of the Bureau of Water Quality and adds 22 
the position of Director of the Bureau of Land Resources. 23

 25

PART LLLL 32 
 33 
This Part provides an exemption from sales tax to certain greenhouse facilities for 34 
95% of the sale price of fuel used by those greenhouse facilities.  The exemption is 35 
repealed December 31, 2019. 36 
PART MMMM 37 
 38 
This Part amends the definition of "lead poisoning" in the Lead Poisoning Control 39 
Act, making the State's standard for lead exposure in children consistent with the federal 40 
standard.  In addition, this Part grants the Department of Health and Human Services 41 
authority to impose penalties for violations of the Lead Poisoning Control Act and the 42 
rules adopted pursuant to that Act. 43 
COMMI TTEE AMENDMENT “A” to H.P. 702, L.D. 1019  
 
 Page 684 - 127LR1852(02)-1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT PART NNNN 1 
 2 
This Part transfers $200,000 from the Fund for a Healthy Maine to the Maine State 3 
Housing Authority and specifies that the funds must be used to provide loans and grants 4 
to low-income homeowners for repairs to remediate arsenic in drinking water. 5 
PART OOOO 6 
 7 
This Part provides that a portion of special revenues received by the Department of 8 
Environmental Protection related to uncontrolled hazardous substance sites must be 9 
transferred to the Board of Environmental Protection Fund.  This will provide for a more 10 
equitable distribution of funding for the board's work, and the board's funding sources 11 
will more accurately reflect the subject matter actually covered by the board. 12 
PART PPPP 13 
 14 
This Part provides an exemption from sales tax and service provider tax for certain 15 
nonprofit library collaborativ es. 16 
PART QQQQ 17 
 18 
This Part maintains the sales tax on lodging, liquor sold in licensed establishments 19 
and prepared food at 8% after July 1, 2015. 20 
PART RRRR 21 
 22 
This Part requires the Legislative Council to solicit bids for the equipment needed for 23 
the Maine Public Broadcasting Network to operate the Maine Capitol Connection 24 
channel. 25 
PART SSSS 26 
 27 
This Part establishes a working group to evaluate the extent to which extremely low- 28 
income households, including families, persons with disabilities and elderly persons, lack 29 
access to safe and affordable housing and the burden that this inadequacy creates for 30 
individuals and communities.  It requires the director of the Maine State Housing 31 
Authority to appoint the members of the working group and convene the first meeting no 32 
later than September 15, 2015 and to report to the Joint Standing Committee on 33 
Appropriations and Financial Affairs and the Joint Standing Committee on Labor, 34 
Commerce, Research and Economic Development with the working group's 35 
recommendations and any suggested legislation no later than December 1, 2015.  It 36 
authorizes the Joint Standing Committee on Labor, Commerce, Research and Economic 37 
Development to report out a bill to implement the legislation. 38
